State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China Graphical abstract Several common ECPs and the main components of Li-S/Se batteries, as well as the specific action mechanism and application of ECPs in Li-S/Se batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries and lithium-selenium (Li-Se) batteries, as environmental protection energy storage systems with outstanding theoretical specific capacities and high energy densities, have become the hotspots of current researches. Besides, elemental S (Se) raw materials are widely sourced and their production costs are both low, which make them considered one of the new generations of high energy density electrochemical energy storage systems with the most potential for development. However, poor conductivity of elemental S/Se and the notorious “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) severely hinder the commercialization of Li-S/Se batteries. Thanks to the excellent electrical conductivity and strong absorption of lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) about electronically conducting polymer, some of the above thorny problems have been effectively alleviated. The review presents the fundamental studies and current development trends of common electronically conducting polymers in various components of Li-S/Se batteries, which involves polyaniline (PANI) polypyrrole (PPy), and polythiophene (PTh) with its derivatives, e.g. polyethoxythiophene (PEDOT) and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS). Finally, the review not only summarizes the research directions and challenges facing the application of electronically conducting polymers, but also looks forward to the development prospects of them, which will provide a way for the practical use of electronically conducting polymers in Li-S/Se batteries with outstanding electrochemical properties in the short run. Keywords Li-S/Se batteries Electronically conducting polymer Various battery components Suppressed “shuttle effect” Outstanding electrochemical properties 1 Introduction In recent years, increasing environmental pollution problems and decreasing fossil fuel energy have forced people to develop renewable energies. Furthermore, with the rapid development of automotive electrification and power grid applications, people have increasingly higher requirements for batteries' energy density. Lithium-ion battery has been widely used in the past decades. However, with the battery's electrochemical performance approaching its theoretical limit, the existing commercial lithium-ion batteries have difficulty meeting the growing demands [1]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have some advantages of excellent theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh∙g−1), high energy density (2600 Wh∙kg−1) and volumetric energy density (2800 Wh∙L-1). Moreover, sulfur is abundant in nature, so using sulfur as cathode materials for Li-S batteries could take advantage of its environmental protection and low price [2]. As for lithium-selenium (Li-Se) batteries, the selenium, belonging to the same group as sulfur in the periodic table, shows a redox mechanism similar to sulfur [3]. Although Li-Se batteries have a lower specific capacity (675 mAh∙g−1) than that of Li-S batteries, their volumetric energy density (2600 Wh∙L-1) is comparable to Li-S batteries [4]. In addition, the conductivity of Se (1 × 10-3 S∙m−1) is much higher than that of S (5 × 10-28 S∙m−1). Hence, considering their respective advantages, these two kinds of secondary batteries can be further developed to meet different requirements. In Li-S cell, the total reaction during the charge and discharge process is given in the following equation:16Li + S8 ↔ 8Li2S. The partial reaction equation occurring on lithium anode: 2Li ↔ Li++2e-, and the partial reaction equation occurring on sulfur cathode: S8 + 16Li++16e-↔8Li2S. The electrochemical reaction of S cathode includes a multi-step redox reaction accompanying a complex phase transfer process of sulfide during discharge process [5], which the simplified reaction equation sequence is S8 → S8 2-→S6 2-/S4 2-→Li2S2/Li2S. However, the conversion process of active sulfur materials is not strictly following the above equation step by step, and the specific reaction is more complicated. For instance, long-chain lithium polysulfide can not only react with metal lithium, but also react with insoluble Li2S2 and Li2S, as well as the lithium polysulfide will undergo a disproportionation reaction [6]. The long-chain lithium polysulfide generated by the cathode diffuses to metal lithium anode due to the existence of concentration gradient and reacts with metal lithium, forming low-order lithium polysulfide. Li2S2 and Li2S will further react with the long-chain lithium polysulfide diffused to the surface of the lithium anode to produce lithium polysulfide with a short segment length. The short-chain lithium polysulfides will diffuse back to the cathode again and be oxidized into long-chain lithium polysulfide during the process of charge. The migration of lithium polysulfide between the cathode and anode of the battery is known as the notorious “shuttle effect”. The general reaction equation of Li-Se batteries is similar to Li-S batteries: Se8 + 16Li ↔ 8Li2Se. All in all, lithium ions and electrons transfer between anode and cathode for these two kinds of batteries, and they store chemical energy through the transformation of electric energy. The Li-S/Se batteries have been developed rapidly in the past few decades and achieved substantial achievements. However, the following points have severely hindered the commercialization of Li-S/Se batteries: 1) Elemental S/Se and their discharge products both have low conductivity, making the electron transport of the electrode material inconvenient. 2). The “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) mentioned above leads to the loss of active material, and the Coulomb efficiency is low. Meanwhile, the specific capacity of Li-S/Se battery is rapidly declining and the insoluble Li2S/Li2S2 (Li2Se/Li2Se2) products are produced to passivate the lithium metal surface, severely reducing the cycle performance. 3). The Li-S/Se batteries generate lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) or lithium sulfide (selenide) with a changing density during the discharge process, which causes the structure of cathode material to expand and contract significantly, making the structure extremely unstable. This is extremely unfavorable for redox reactions and will trigger a large amount of capacity attenuation. 4). When metal lithium is used as the electrode of battery, lithium dendrites are usually formed in the organic electrolyte. If the dendrite grows too long, it will pierce the separator and cause a short circuit inside the battery [7]. In order to solve these thorny problems, many researchers have conducted in-depth research on the cathodes, anodes, electrolytes, separators and additives of Li-S/Se batteries. As a result, researches on functional materials to improve Li-S/Se batteries are the basis for further development. Electronically conducting polymers (abbreviated as ECPs) have good electrical properties of metals and excellent flexibility/processability of organic polymers. Furthermore, some ECPs contain functional atoms (e.g., N, S, O) that can absorb lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), making them widely used in the field of Li-S/Se batteries. Moreover, the researchers combined ECPs with carbon and polar materials to form composite materials, and the synergy between the composite materials makes the performance of Li-S/Se batteries more superior. Presently, the ECPs mainly used in Li-S/Se batteries are polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), and polythiophene (PTh) with its derivatives, e.g., poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) [8]. The main functions of these ECPs in Li-S/Se batteries are used as the sulfur host, redox mediators, coating layers (coated on cathodes or separators), interlayers, and binders to improve the electrical conductivity of cathode, alleviate the volume expansion and inhibit the dissolution of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), thereby significantly improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S/Se batteries. The application of common ECPs toward advanced Li-S/Se batteries is presented in Fig. 1 . Recently, unprecedented research activities have been carried out for the development of ECPs materials to solve the above problems. Nevertheless, the rationally designed ECPs with unique structures combined with carbon materials and polar materials (e.g., polar metal oxides and metal–organic frameworks) toward advanced Li-S/Se batteries about the review is still in blank now. In this review, we aim to provide an overview on the development of classification and the synthesis methods for ECPs and their derivatives, understanding the synergistic effect and role of ECPs combining the physical and chemical adsorption for Li-S/Se batteries including cathodes, binders, separators and interlayers. Lastly, this review generalizes the applications of ECPs materials in Li-S/Se cells and proposes the possible directions in making full use of different properties of ECPs materials to promote the fast development of Li-S/Se batteries. 2 ECPs introduction The concept of conducting polymers (CPs) first originated in 1977, when scientists MacDiarmid et al. found that doped polyacetylene films can obtain the high conductivity of similar metals. For more than 40 years since then, people have carried out much research on the preparation methods of CPs and their conductive mechanisms, achieving remarkable achievements. Nowadays, the CPs can be divided into compound and intrinsic CPs according to their composition [9]. Intrinsic CPs refer to polymer materials that can achieve conductive functions through their own structures. According to the conductive mechanism, intrinsic CPs can be divided into electronic conducting polymers (ECPs) and ionic conducting polymers. Some ECPs are insulators in their intrinsic state, but after doping treatment, the conductivities of the polymers are enhanced to reach the level of semiconductor or conductor. ECPs have a linear or planar conjugated structure, and the molecular skeleton is a localized σ bond and the P orbitals in the vertical domain form delocalized bonds. When the degree of polymerization is low, the electrons in the polymer are mostly localized or partially delocalized, and the degree of conjugation increases with the growth of the conjugated chain, leading to the enhancement of the delocalization ability of the electrons. When the molecular chain is long enough, free electrons will appear, thus possessing the ability to conduct electricity [10]. In a word, the conductive principle of ECPs is that under the action of an electric field, carriers (holes or free electrons) follow the polymer molecules chain migration or inter-chain leaping form a macroscopic current and conduct conduction [11]. The main preparation methods used in the synthesis of ECPs are chemical oxidation and electrochemical polymerization. In the chemical oxidation method, solution polymerization, interfacial polymerization and template polymerization are mainly used to synthesize ECPs in this review. Chemical oxidation usually uses water-soluble initiator to initiate oxidative polymerization of monomers in acidic medium. The electrochemical polymerization method is to oxidize and polymerize the monomers in the electrolyte on the surface of the inert electrode under the action of an electric field to directly obtain a polymer film with a strong binding force to the electrode matrix. Due to their unique properties, ECPs are not only widely used as conductive materials, but also have potential application value in energy, optoelectronic devices, sensors and other fields. ECPs have much smaller density than other conductive materials. Meanwhile, they also have high conductivity and large specific surface area at room temperature, which are exquisite electrode materials for batteries. Besides, due to some ECPs have strong chemical adsorption to lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) [12], ECPs have been extensively studied in different components of Li-S/Se batteries. The detailed schematic diagram of function mechanism and structure designing based on ECPs for Li-S/Se batteries are shown in Fig. 2 . 3 Cathodes Elemental S/Se are the primary materials of the cathodes for Li-S/Se batteries. However, because of the insulating properties of S and the low conductivity of Se, S/Se basically has no solid crystal structure to form a solid electrode, and no cage structure to accommodate lithium ions. Therefore, the cathode cannot merely be made of S/Se [13]. Given the above problems, researchers have proposed that elemental S/Se could be used in combination with different materials (carbon, conductive polymers, metal-organic frameworks, etc.). 3.1 S/Se with ECPs The most traditional cathode material is carbon-based S/Se composite material. However, the lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) has low binding energy with the non-polar carbon matrix and the lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) aggregates are easily desorbed from the carbon matrix, resulting in the loss of electrochemical contact sites [14]. For these problems, researchers introduced ECPs rich in polar sites in the cathode materials of Li-S/Se batteries. The application of ECPs to the cathode improves the conductivity and reduces the “shuttle effect”. 3.1.1 S/Se with PANI As early as 1987, Macdiarmid et al. [15] proposed a model of PANI, which regarded PANI as a copolymer of phenylenediamine and quinodiimide, as shown in Table S1. The “polyaniline” mentioned in the general literature refers to the intermediate oxidation state (y = 0.5) unless otherwise specified. After that, PANI has become a research hotspot because of its cheap and readily available raw materials, simple synthesis method and friendly environment. Moreover, PANI has a theoretical specific capacity of 294 mAh∙g−1, which can participate in the redox reaction of the electrode in the same area as the S-S bond of the elemental S [16]. Furthermore, PANI also has a strong immobilization capacity for chemically capturing migrating lithium polysulfide (polyselenide). The trapping mechanism is due to the chemical interaction between the S/Se-containing species and the quinonoid imine (N) of the quinone ring. Therefore, when PANI participates in modifying the cathode materials, it not only plays the role of adsorbing material but also acts as active material and conductive agent. In Li-S battery, the vulcanization method has been adopted by researchers to obtain the vulcanized polyaniline/sulfur (SPANI/S) composite. Vulcanization is a cross-linking reaction of sulfur that produces a three-dimensional network structure in rubber [17]. It is reported that the S8 ring can open and decompose into chain sulfur (S n ) when the temperature is higher than 175℃ [18]. Furthermore, PANI and S will generate the chemical bond during heating treatment, which is beneficial to inhibit the “shuttle effect”. Liu et al. [19] adopted the soft template method to self-assemble aniline monomers and then vulcanized them with sublimed S, forming a three-dimensional, cross-linked and structurally stable main chain of sulfur-polyaniline nanotubes (SPANI-NT) polymer (Fig. 3 a). The role of the polymer matrix was to act as a self-breathing framework that allowed lithium polysulfides to undergo reversible in situ deposition subsequent transformation within the polymer matrix and adapt to volume changes. The Li-S battery with the cathode delivered a discharge capacity of 837 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C rate and manifested stable cycling capacity up to 500 cycles at 1 C. In order to illustrate the detailed molecular structure of such SPANI/S nanostructures, they also prepared the SPANI/S composites with different S contents. They concluded that a part of S was grafted on PANI during heating and jointed the PANI chains with disulfide bonds to form a crosslinked network, however, the remanent of S particles and lithium polysulfide were physically encapsulated in the polymer network [20]. Yan et al. [21] fabricated the nanoporous sulfur-polyaniline (SPANI) with coral-like nanopore structure by a two-step reaction (Fig. 3b). Many nanoflakes in the structure provided a large specific surface area that provided more electroactive sites for sulfur and fixed lithium polysulfide to reduce sulfur aggregation, leading to the SPANI cathode had high cycling capacity over 200 cycles at 2 C. The possible mechanism of the SPANI composite was presented in Fig. 3(c). However, further research is needed to understand the mechanism of disulfide bond reaction and improve the performance of Li-S batteries. Ma et al. [22] attached sulfur to the inner and outer surfaces of PANI hollow spheres via vapour phase infusion and heating treatment. Most of the sulfur encapsulated in PANI hollow spheres were captured by the cross-linked stereo PANI-S network and PANI shell, providing excellent cycle stability over the following cycles. The phenomenon could be explained by the formation of C-S bond during heat treatment and the structure of PANI hollow sphere, which inhibited the dissolution and migration of lithium polysulfide in electrolyte and improved cathode conductivity, as well as restrained the volume expansion of cathode. The schematics of the PANI-S composite during the charge–discharge process as shown in Fig. 3(d), and the prepared PANI-S cathode maintained an outstanding discharge capacity of 602 mAh g−1 even after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C. Zhou et al. [23] reported the synthesis of a polyaniline-sulfur (PANI-S) yolk-shell nanocomposite (Fig. 3e) via a heating vulcanization. Through heat treatment, the obtained PANI-coated S was partially distilled off, leaving a certain space inside the PANI shell structure to accommodate the volume change, so that the structural integrity of the composite could be well maintained. Compared with the S-PANI core–shell structure, the cyclability of the egg-yolk shell nanostructure was greatly improved, which had a specific discharge capacity of 765 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at a current density of 0.2 C. However, using the heating treatment method to mix the sulfur and ECPs requires long periods of time and may affect their original structure. In the face of the issue, Lu et al. [24] prepared the S/PANI composite and 3D urchin-like structure by a very soft and facile one-step approach. The prepared S/PANI composite has the advantages of low cost and easy production without conducting additive. Moreover, the obtained 3D urchin-like electrode for Li-S batteries had an initial discharge capacity of 1095 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and retained good discharge capacity at 832 mAh g−1 (0.2 C) and 609 mAh g−1 (1.0 C). The template method was also commonly used to make PANI/S composites without heat-treatment process. Based on previous work, Gao et al. [25] introduced polyaniline nanowires with phosphate ester as dopant, and took the nanowires as template to design and synthesize an ideal ultrathin sulfur layer (10 nm) wrapped polyaniline nanofiber composite (S-PANI) with core–shell structure as presented in Fig. 4 (a). Compared with the previously reported S-PANI composite materials, the PANI nanofibers were thinner (average diameter 70 nm). In addition, no heat treatment was performed from beginning to end, so the conductive substrate retained its original structure and good conductivity. The prepared S-PANI electrode exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 977 mAh g−1 and had 88.3% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C. Some researchers firstly deposited sulfur and PANI on silica template by chemical deposition method and then corroded the template by hydrofluoric acid to obtain the hollow PANI/S (hPANIs@S) composite. Wei et al. [26] manufactured the hPANIs@S composite by using a three-step process as shown in Fig. 4(b). The hollow structure of hPANI could provide an effective conductive network and decrease volume change. Based on the work, another PANI layer was added outside the sulfur by Fan’s group [27]. The double PANI layers have the advantages of providing multiple ways for convenient lithium-ion penetration, inhibiting lithium polysulfides from entering organic solutions, and overcoming volume expansion. Their group also used MCM-41 as template to fabricated the hollow PANI/S composite, and the difference was that the deposition sequence of PANI and sulfur was reversed. Furthermore, there was just only one PANI layer on the sulfur surface, playing the role of providing many electronic conduction pathways to improve electrochemical performance [28]. A copolymer can be synthesized based on one kind of polymer with another polymer by grafting method, and the physical and chemical properties of the polymer could be thoroughly modified [29]. Dai et al. [30] synthesized conducting PANI containing sulfur-rich copolymer/sulfur composite i.e. cp (S-g-PANI)/S (abbreviated as SPAS) by a two-step method. The specific synthetic route diagram of SAS and SPA is shown in Fig. 4(c). After grafting conductive polymer segments, the capacity and rate capability of SPAS cathodes were significantly improved, which exhibited good cycling stability at 0.5 C. Aniline and phytic acid (PA) copolymerized in situ on graphene oxide (GO) was reported by Zhang’s group [31]. The copolymer contained enriched quinonoid imine, which was proposed to anchor polysulfides and promote the formation of Li2S2/Li2S through a reversible chemical transition between the protonated state (NH+ ) and the deprotonated state (N) under the action of extrinsic PA (Fig. 4d). The work not only explicitly explored the specific role of undetected N-containing groups in Li-S cell, but also shed new light on the organic redox mediators for reversible modulation of electrochemical reactions. In order to improve the conductivity of PANI, dopants are often introduced to achieve improved results. Dodecyl benzene sulfonic acid (DBSA) was selected as the doping agent to improve the conductivity of PANI by Sovizi and co-workers [32]. They prepared the honeycomb polyaniline-dodecyl benzene sulfonic acid (hPANI-DBSA) film through the breath figure (BF) method (Fig. 4e) and then the sulfur was electrodeposited on the honeycomb membrane surface (hPANI-DBSA/S). The cathode without binder showed a higher capacity and long cycle stability. In Li-Se batteries, hollow spherical electrode materials have proved to be one of the materials to improve electrochemical performance due to the porous hollow structure and large pore volume. PANI is selected as the precursor of nitrogen-containing hollow carbon spheres (HCSs) due to its high N/C ratio, good design morphology and high-temperature stability. Li et al. [33] obtained the N-containing HCSs through carbonizing the hollow PANI. The SEM and elemental mapping images of HCSs were presented in Fig. 4(f). When the hollow carbonized PANI was used as a storage material for the Se cathode, its good conductivity increased the depth of reaction. Besides, its hollow structure and nitrogen-atoms effectively trapped Se and Li2Sen. Hence, the HCPS/Se cathode with high Coulombic efficiency could exhibit an initial discharge capacity of 571.5 mAh g−1 and remain 298.7 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 337.5 mA g−1. 3.1.2 S/Se with PPy PPy, as an ECPs, contains a large π bond and has a conjugated structure with CC single bonds and CC double bonds alternately arranged. Researchers often use PPy in the cathode material of Li-S/Se batteries, which could effectively solve the disadvantages of low conductivity, volume expansion and the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides). In Li-S batteries, the easiest method of obtaining the PPy/S composite is to directly polymerize PPy layer in situ on the surface of sulfur particles [34] or firstly polymerized PPy and then mixed sulfur by some methods (e.g. ball-milling method [35]). The in-situ polymerization of pyrrole monomer on the nano-sulfur spheres to get the core–shell structured S@PPy composite was reported by Zhao’s group [36], and the schematic illustration of the synthesis process as shown in Fig. 5 (a). The PPy layer availed to inhibit the aggregation of small sulfur particles, the dissolution and shuttling of lithium polysulfides, as well as provide fast and efficient transport of electrons/lithium ions. What is more, the flexible PPy layer also effectively restrained the volume expansion. Subsequently, they by means of exchanging Cl- with P O 4 3 - prepared the partial P O 4 3 - doped PPy layer, and the addition of P O 4 3 - with a large ion radius made the PPy expand the volume and create a larger space, which was conducive to the penetration of electrolyte to improve the cycling stability and rate performance of S@PPy cathode. Liang et al. [37] firstly prepared the S@PPy composite (PPy as the internal layer) and then coated PPy layer on their surface, getting the three-layer PPy@S@PPy composite with 3D structure. Compared with the S@PPy composite cathode, the three-layer 3D-structure of PPy@S@PPy cathode showed the more excellent electrochemical performance to Li-S battery. Silica microsphere array as template, pyrrole monomer as raw material and ferric chloride as oxidant could be used to prepare mesoporous PPy with open skeleton structure and high specific surface area [38]. Ma et al. [39] synthesized the thin wall hollow polypyrrole (T-HSSP) as the sulfur host using a modified silica sphere as template through the vapour phase infusion method. The SEM and elemental mapping images of T-HSSP illustrated that the PPy thin walls can be obtained (Fig. 5b), which inhibited the dissolution and migration of lithium polysulfides encapsulated in the T-HSSP. Besides, due to the existence of sufficient internal voids in the S@PPy composite, the volume expansion of the cathode during the charge/discharge process was suppressed, making for the cathode showed an initial reversible capacity of 1563.3 mAh g−1 and remained at 892.4 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C. Yin et al. [40] also made use of dual-template (anodic aluminum oxide membranes and silica nanospheres) to fabricate mesoporous PPy nanowires (OMPW) by chemical polymerization (Fig. 5c). The prepared OMPW exhibited a large specific surface area and ordered mesoporous structure as the sulfur host. Compared with the PPy nanoparticles, the one-dimensional OMPW had more stable mechanical properties and provided more active sites. Other templates were also used to synthesize PPy to encapsulate S. Jin et al. [41] firstly established PPy framework with an inverse opal structure and then accommodate S via the melting infiltration method. The PPy framework used dispersed polystyrene nanoparticles as a template by in situ polymerization. Because of the flexibility of PPy and the partial filling of the inverse opal structure to suppress the possible expansion and deformation, the long cycle stability of using the prepared material as a cathode has been greatly improved. Liu et al. [42] utilized the Fe3O4 nanospheres as the template to synthesize ultra-thin wrinkled shell polypyrrole hollow nanosphere (PHNS) via in situ polymerization method, which served as sulfur host to fabricate S@PHNS composite through a melt-diffusion method. The unique ultra-thin wrinkled surface structure of PHNS (Fig. 5d) facilitated the access of electrolyte and effectively adjusted the volume change. The optimum S@PHNS based cathode showed high initial discharge capacity of 1500.5 mAh.g−1 at 0.1 C and 536.5 mAh.g−1 even at 5 C. Using FeCl3 as oxidant and methyl orange (MO) as the chemical template can synthesize the PPy of hollow nanotubular structures by the self-degraded method [43]. Hyun et al. [44] prepared the tubular PPy as the sulfur host via the self-degraded method. The PPy/S cathode with tubular structures had a better performance than the bare sulfur cathode. Besides, they concluded that the amount of FeCl3 oxidant influenced the shape and production of PPy. Increasing the amount of oxidant was generally beneficial to the improvement of the synthesis efficiency of PPy. Wei et al. [45] also used the self-degraded method to fabricate the porous PPy nanotubes for sulfur deposition. They revealed that the remained Fe3+ ions in oxidant promoted the uniform rough sulfur layer formation because of the disproportionation reaction with Na2S2O3. The porous conductive PPy nanotubes played the role of promoting electrolyte diffusion as well as ion and electron transport, enhancing the PPy@S/Fe cathode electrochemical performance. The tubular PPy mentioned later had been made by this method with the same effect. Using PPy as the precursor, the N-doped porous carbon materials can be prepared through carbonization and a subsequent KOH activation. During the carbonization process, the N atoms, i.e. pyrrolic N (N-5) in the PPy five-membered ring, were partially converted to pyridinic N (N-6) and quaternary N (N-Q) [46]. Abundant N-6 and N-Q can provide chemically active sites and increase battery power density [47]. Due to the strong interatomic attraction between the basic pyridinic N and lithium polysulfide, the carbon adsorption capacity of lithium polysulfide can be improved. The N-5 supplied the π system with two p-electrons in the PPy molecular structure, and even if its interaction for lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) is not as strong as pyridinic N, it may also be able to improve surface adsorption performance [48]. Yang et al. [49] reported the functionalized N-doped porous carbon nanofiber/sulfur (N-PCNF/S) composite prepared by pyrolysis of PPy nanofibers and subsequent KOH activation as an advanced Li-S battery cathode material. The prepared N-PCNF had large specific surface area of 2642 m2 g−1 and high inner pore volume of 1.31 cm3 g−1, which could encapsulate a large amount of sulfur and realize fast and long-distance electron transmission as shown in Fig. 6 (a). In addition, N doping enhanced surface adsorption and further inhibited the diffusion of lithium polysulfides. Hence, the N-PCNF/S cathode could maintain a stable capacity of 666.0 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles even at 1 C. In order to get the N,S-codoped carbons, Antonio’s group [50] mixed the PPy with sodium thiosulfate and KCl through heat-treated, and then immersed in HCl solution to fabricated the S/C composite (Fig. 6b). The sodium thiosulfate acted as the activating agent, sulfur precursor and S dopant. The N, S-codoped carbons had over 2000 m2 g−1 surface areas and a micro-mesoporous structure, leading to the S/C composites as the cathode delivered a high specific capacity of 1100 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and above 500 mAh g−1 at 2 C with sulfur contents in the 50 ~ 80 wt%. Zhang et al. [51] carbonized the tubular PPy (T-PPy) and then activated the carbonized T-PPy used potassium hydroxide to obtain the K-non-graphitizable carbon (K-NGC) as the sulfur host. The as-prepared K-NGC/S cathode delivered excellent electrochemical properties for Li-S batteries due to the conductive K-NGC material. Li et al. [52] acquired the tubular amorphous carbon (TAC) by carbonizing the tubular PPy to offer sulfur deposition, and the following was coated the PPy layer on the TAC@S composite to form the core–shell structured TAC@S@PPy composite (Fig. 6c). The core–shell structured composite as the cathode for Li-S batteries exhibited an initial discharge specific capacity of 1111 mAh g−1 and retained 731 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 335 mA g−1. In Li-Se batteries, as early as in 2013, Kundu et al. [53] had reported the PPy as the coating layer (8 ~ 12 nm thickness) directly coated trigonal selenium nanofibers (20 ~ 50 nm) as cathode material via surfactant-free solution method, and the TEM image of polypyrrole coated Se fibers was presented in Fig. 6(d). The results showed that the PPy coating layer improved the packaging capacity of the material by withstanding large-volume shrinkage and expansion. Soon after, Guo et al. [54] prepared the PPy hollow spheres as the Se host through a modified template method [39]. The hollow sphere structure of PPy physically hampered the lithium polyselenide dissolution and buffered the volume expansion to a certain extent. Moreover, via Raman analysis, they speculated that part of the chain-like Se in the composite material had a certain interaction with the C atom in CC of PPy, which played a role in inhibiting the “shuttle effect” of lithium polyselenide. The hollow Se@PPy cathode for Li-Se batteries could obtain a stable discharge capacity of 400 mAh/g at 0.2 C (1 C = 675mAh.g−1) after 80 cycles with a nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency. Same as Li-S batteries, for the sake of manufacturing the N-doped microporous carbon spheres, some group also have been reported that the prepared PPy spheres could be carbonized with an appropriate amount of KOH as an activator to obtain N-doped carbon spheres as the storage material of Se [46,55,56]. For instance, Huang's group [46] prepared the carbonized PPy (CP). Through SEM and TEM tests (Fig. 6e), they observed that CP has a three-dimensional building structure with large pores and selenium was evenly dispersed and injected into the internal micropores. They also confirmed that N and O atoms were well introduced into the carbon framework and chemically bound to C, causing asymmetric charge and spin density in the carbon layer. The resulting charge delocalization provided high conductivity and electrochemical properties in CP. Finally, they proved the superior electrochemical performance of the Se-CP cathode through the electrochemical performance test, which delivered the rate capability as high as 303 mAh g−1 even at 20 C (1 C = 675 mAh g−1) and maintained 506 mAh g−1 even after 150 cycles at 1 C. 3.1.3 S/Se with PTh and its derivatives Polythiophene (PTh), as a crucial ECPs, is also directly used in Li-S/Se batteries research. As early as 2011 years, Chen’s group prepared the sulfur/polythiophene composite with a core–shell structure through an in-situ chemical oxidation polymerization process. The composite had stable cycling performance because the sulfur was coated with conductive PTh, which improved the electrode conductivity and prevented the agglomeration of particles. In addition, the porous structure contributed to absorb lithium polysulfide and reduce its diffusion into the liquid electrolyte [57]. Li et al. [58] did a similar experiment that PTh lamella was coated on the sulfur particles via in situ polymerization. As a conductive and soft additive, the PTh lamella could improve the conductivity of electrode and the utilization rate of sulfur. Sörgel’s groups had reported sulfur particles functionalized with PTh and then were applied to the surface of nickel foam [59] (Fig. 7 a) and copper foil [60] through composite electroplating method, respectively. The PTh was to ensure the wettability and dispersibility of sulfur particles in the electrolyte, and make the particle surface have partial conductivity to initiate the growth of a structured composite layer during the composite electroplating process. Subsequently, there were almost no reports about the direct application of pure PTh to S/Se cathode. However, its derivatives had been widely used in Li-S batteries. For instance, Oschmann et al. [61] reported a copolymer (S-P3HT), which the covalent linkage of long sulfur chains to allyl-terminated with one segment compatible with elementary S and the other segment compatible with P3HT, obtained by Grenal conversion decomposition polymerization of sulfur and propylene-terminated poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) (P3HT) (Fig. 7b). Using the homogeneous S-P3HT copolymer combined with sulfur particles as the cathode, the strong interaction between polysulfide and polythiophene reduced the loss of active substances and lowered the electrical resistance, which improved the electrochemical performance. As one of the derivatives of PTh, PEDOT has currently received widespread attention in commercial conducting polymers. There are two main types of PEDOT currently in the actual application. One is PEDOT polymer obtained by chemical oxidation or electrochemical polymerization of 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT) monomer. The other is PEDOT: PSS aqueous solution, in which PEDOT is coated by high molecular weight PSS through coulomb interaction and dispersed in water. The PEDOT:PSS aqueous solution has excellent film-forming property and the PEDOT:PSS film has excellent flexibility. Many advantages make PEDOT:PSS a promising new energy material for researchers. In Li-S batteries, about the application of PEDOT, ultrafine sulfur nanoparticles (10 ~ 20 nm in diameter) were synthesized by membrane-assisted precipitation method. Afterward, PEDOT was polymerized on the sulfur nanoparticles surface as the conducting layer to form the core–shell S/PEDOT composites for Li-S battery. Comparing nano-S with S/PEDOT cathodes, the latter had better electrochemical performance, which was since the PEDOT layer not only limited the diffusion of lithium polysulfides but also decreased the volume change during the cycles [62]. Ding et al. [63] synthesized the porous PEDOT/S composite (pPEDOT/S) via in-situ confinement strategy, and the fabrication route and structure of pPEDOT/S composite were presented in Fig. 7(c). Porous nanostructures could promote the rapid diffusion of electrolytes and adapt to volume expansion. The chemical interaction between heteroatom and lithium polysulfide in the PEDOT framework could mitigate the dissolution of lithium polysulfide, which enhanced the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries assembled with pPEDOT/S cathode performance. Meanwhile, PEDOT:PSS, like PEDOT as coating layer of sulfur, also was applied for Li-S cell. Anilkumar et al. [64] dispersed the sulfur powder and PEDOT:PSS into the water to synthesize the sulfur/PEDOT:PSS nanocomposite via hydrothermal approach as shown in Fig. 7(d). The PEDOT:PSS played a coating layer role, which improved the conductivity of the electrode, prevented lithium polysulfides from dissolving into the electrolytes and controlled the volume expansion of sulfur as a buffer layer at high lithium intake. Using the sulfur/PEDOT:PSS nanocomposite as Li-S battery cathode showed an initial capacity of 897 mAh g−1 at 1 C and retained the capacity of 664 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. The PEDOT:PSS also directly coated on the surface of sulfur powder through the wet mixing method in water [65], which also revealed that the PEDOT:PSS coating could facilitate the utilization rate of sulfur and improve the capacity of sulfur cathode. Zeng et al. [66] mixed the sulfur with poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) (P3HT) to copolymerized them through radical polymerization. After that, capping them with PEDOT:PSS layer to synthesize the homogeneous copolymer noted as CP(S3BT). Among the CP(S3BT) composite, S had lots of covalent bonds with 3-butylthiophene (in the P3BT backbone) formed the cross-linking networks. Moreover, the capped PEDOT:PSS not only improved the electrical conductivity but also mitigated the dissolution of lithium polysulfide. So compared with the pure sulfur cathode, using the CP(S3BT) composite as the active material for Li-S battery cathode exhibited excellent electrochemical performance, which delivered a capacity of 682 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles. In Li-Se batteries, Zhao et al. [67] mixed PEDOT and KOH to obtain sulfur atom and oxygen atom co-doped hierarchical carbon (SO-HPC) through the carbonization/activation process. Subsequently, the prepared Se/SO-HPC composites were prepared by the melt diffusion (Fig. 7e). They prepared a mixture of different weight ratios of KOH and PEDOT, as well as different weight ratios of Se. The results through experiments showed that the prepared SO-HPC could not only effectively fix Se, but also avoid the side reaction of Se anions in carbonate-based electrolytes. Besides, they also calculated the binding energy between Li2Se containing heteroatom (O and S) dopants and the carbon host using first principles and concluded that co-doping of O and S in carbon significantly improved the adsorption of Li2Se. To further clarify the actual impact of heteroatom dopants on electrochemical performance, they also used activated carbon without heteroatoms to carry Se. The results showed that heteroatoms (S and O) had a significant effect on the electrochemical performance of batteries. Among all the different weight ratios, the Se50/SO-HPC3 cathode (viz. the ratio of KOH to PEDOT is 3:1 and Se content is 50 wt%) displayed low self-discharge performance and good cyclic performance, showing a reversible capacity of 450 mAh g−1 even after 1700 cycles at 0.5 C (1 C = 675 mAh g−1) with always almost 100% coulomb efficiency at room temperature. 3.2 S/Se with ECPs and carbon materials When the ECPs were used alone to modify the S/Se cathode, due to the lack of efficient rigid S/Se conductive frame, it can cause the active material to be dissolved in the electrolyte once the flexible coating layer is damaged, causing irreversible capacity loss. Carbonaceous materials, as the ideal carriers for S/Se, have lightweight, good electrical conductivity and stable structure [68]. However, the intermolecular interactions between nonpolar carbon and polar Li x S/ Li x Se (0 < x ≤ 2) are too weak to inhibit lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) shuttling. Researchers had made full use of the advantages of ECPs and rigid carbonaceous materials. Through the synergy of ECPs and various carbon-based materials, a variety of S/Se with ECPS and carbon-based cathode have been prepared, achieving rigidity and flexibility in structure, complementing each other in electrical conductivity, and realizing high rate charge and long cycle performance. 3.2.1 S/Se with PANI and carbon materials In Li-S batteries, when PANI, carbon and sulfur are used together as the primary materials of the cathodes, it can be divided into the following three types of form configurations: 1). The carbon materials first encapsulated sulfur and then they are covered with PANI (S/C/PANI). 2). The PANI grows on carbon materials and then elemental sulfur deposits on them (C/PANI/S). 3). The PANI is coated on the sulfur and then they are wrapped with carbon materials (S/PANI/C). The first type of form configuration (S/C/PANI) is the most reported one. Carbon is the main host materials, and PANI is just as the functional coating layer coated on the surface of S/C composites, which avoids direct contact between S and electrolyte, improves the conductivity of the electrode and suppresses the shuttle of lithium polysulfide. The CNTs had excellent electrical and mechanical properties, especially high electron mobility, considered the good sulfur host material. Kim et al. [69]and Li et al. [70] reported about the PANI coated on the S/SWNT and MWCNTs-S (Fig. 8 a) composites, respectively. Porous carbon is also the good sulfur host material, so the PANI materials were coated on different porous carbon/sulfur composites by in-situ polymerization to form the primary cathode materials with different shapes. For instance, the sandwich-type porous carbon composite/S [71], S/spherical ordered mesoporous carbon [72] and S/mesoporous carbon CMK3 composite [73]. The conductive PANI coating layer prevented sulfur from directly contacting the electrolyte, inhibited the outward diffusion of lithium polysulfide and accommodated large volume changes. Besides, the PANI also was selected to coat on other different types of carbon/S composite. Tang et al. [74] coated the PANI on the surface of activated carbon aerogel/sulfur (ACA-500-S), obtaining the ACA-500-S@PANi composite for Li-S cell (Fig. 8b). The ACA-500 had high surface area and unique 3D interconnected hierarchical porous structure. Moreover, the PANI coating layer improved the conductivity of the cathode and inhibited the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides, leading to the prepared ACA-500-S@PANi cathode delivered an initial capacity of 926 mAh g−1 and maintained a specific capacity of 615 mAh g−1 after 700 cycles (at 1 C). Zhang’s group [75] coated PANi on carbon nanofiber/sulfur (CNF/S) composite. The PANi layer, as shown in Fig. 8(c), played an electrical bridge role in the electron transfer between S and CNFs. As a result, the cathode could maintain discharge capacities of 953 and 552 mAh g−1 at 0.2 and 1 C after 300 cycles, respectively. Yao et al. [76] synthesized PANI by a dilute polymerization method to wrap super P/S. They found out that even if PANI loading was ca. 1 wt%, it could improve the cycle performance of the battery. Zou et al. [77] and Sun et al.et al. [78] did a similar work that they both coated the PANI on acetylene black/sulfur composite surface. The coating of PANI on their surface was beneficial to the inward diffusion of the liquid electrolyte and the passage of Li+. Furthermore, it also had a strong affinity for lithium polysulfide, which limited the dissolution of lithium polysulfide. Therefore, the PANI coating layer played the multiple roles of conductive additive and porous adsorbent in the composite. Yu’s group [79] reported the PANI as the coating layer (5 nm) was coated on the colloidal carbon /S composite. The colloidal carbon sphere had a high elastic coefficient and adequate space for suppressing the volume expansion during cycle process. Furthermore, the PANI coating layer further inhibited the diffusion of lithium polysulfide and improved the stability of cathode during the electrochemical cycle, leading to this kind of cathode with the PANI coated S/C nanosphere showed excellent long cycle capability even over 2500 cycles at 5 C with a capacity decay of 0.01% per cycle (Fig. 8d). By introducing –SO3H group on PANI chain, the SPANI was obtained [80]. In Li-S batteries, the –SO3H group can provide powerful chemical anchoring for lithium polysulfides. Wei et al. [81] selected the PANI and SPANI to coated on the surface of bamboo-derived porous carbon/sulfur composites, respectively. The -SO3H group of SPANI improved the transmission rate of electrons and lithium ions and optimized the reaction kinetics, which significantly improved cycling stability and superior rate performance of the electrode. Zhao et al. [82] prepared the 3D-hybrid cathode, in which the SPANI coated on the N-GO/CNT hybrid framework with loading sulfur composite. The prepared SPANI had good electrons/lithium ions dual conductivity to further improve the electron and ion transport of the whole cathode so that the 3D-hybrid cathode could maintain a discharge capacity of 438.3 mAh g−1 after 450 cycles even at a superhigh current density of 7.5 A/g. Graphene is suitable as a storage material for Li-S battery due to its large specific surface area, high conductivity, excellent mechanical strength, and flexible structure. It can prevent the loss of active materials and improve the performance of Li-S batteries. Based on these advantages, the application of ECPs, together with graphene for Li-S batteries, has been extensively studied and reported. Qiu et al. [83] deposited the S on the graphene oxide (GO) sheets via a chemical deposition method in an aqueous solution in which simultaneously added 5 wt% surfactant of CTAB, fabricating the CTAB-GO-S composite. Finally, the PANI layer was coated on the surface of the composite. They previously concluded that the CTAB modified GO nanocomposites as the sulfur host for Li-S batteries could enhance the cycling performance. However, the addition of the PANI layer further increases the electrochemical performance because the PANI improved the electrode’s conductivity and adsorb lithium polysulfide through chemical action. Similar to the previous experiment, Ding et al. [84] deposited the nano-sulfur on the nitrogen-doped GO sheets (NGNS) surface and then coated PANI layer, forming the ternary-layered nanoarchitecture NGNS-S-PANI composite (Fig. 8e). Owing to the conductive PANI coating layer and the ternary-layered nanoarchitecture, the cathodes delivered an initial capacity of 1344.2 mAh/g and 1277.3 mAh/g, respectively, and maintained a specific capacity of 694 mAh/g and 552 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 0.5 C, respectively. Crosslinked polymer by heating could reduce the permeability of the layer because the polymer chains are rearranged into the preferred structure [85]. Kim’s group [86] successfully prepared the GO-S@PANI composites, using a layer-by-layer assembly technique combined with a heat treatment method. They mentioned that the rearrangement procedure of polymer chains was accompanied by the increase in conductivity, elastic modulus and polymer polycondensation, resulting in a decrease in pore size. The cross-linked PANI layer increased the diffusion rate of electrons and lithium ions, greatly reducing the outward penetration of lithium polysulfide and inhibiting their shuttle. The PANI also was coated on the surface of the curved graphene (CG) that encapsulates sulfur to get the CG-S@PANI composite. The PANI coating enhances the electrochemical performance of cathode and also protects it from self-discharge. Moreover, they point out that the curved form of CG was favorable for sulfur loading when compared with the sheets form [87]. The second type of form configuration (C/PANI/S) is to use carbon as the growth of PANI and then sulfur is deposited between them. Deng et al. [88] introduced carbon nanotube/polyaniline/graphene (MWCNT-PANI-G) composite as sulfur host (Fig. 9 a). The outermost graphene and innermost MWCNTs improved the cathode conductivity, provided a stable skeleton and accelerated the ion conduction. Furthermore, the middle section of PANI could absorb soluble lithium polysulfides. The synergy of the three improves the electrochemical performance of the battery. Wang et al. [89] chose PANI wrapped on the surface of oxidized carbon black forming a conducting spherical network through self-assembly and grafting method, and the elemental S was then poured into the pores of the spherical network to fabricate the C-S@PANI composite. The conductive PANI not only improved the utilization rate of active substances but also enhanced the dual conduction of Li+ and electrons, as well as encapsulated sulfur in the PANI hollow spherical network. Zhang’s group [90] reported the PANI polymerized in situ on graphene sheets and then sulfur nanoparticles are simultaneously deposited in the PANI layer. GO was used as an oxidant to polymerize aniline monomers into PANI, while reducing GO to graphene. As a conductive skeleton, graphene was beneficial to enhance the utilization of S and the reactivity of composite materials. Moreover, PANI provided a reaction chamber for sulfur particles, preventing lithium polysulfides from diffusing. Li et al. [91] made the PANI grow on the surface of graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) to obtain the PANI-GNRs composite as the sulfur host. In the PANI-GNRs composite, the GNRs improved the mechanical properties of the composite, thereby enhancing the ability of electrode to recover from volume expansion. And the PANI could trap lithium polysulfide through physical and chemical absorption, thereby suppressing their shuttle effect. The PANI used as a precursor for porous carbon materials was studied by Lu's groups [92], and they prepared the precursor of mesoporous carbon core material (p-MC) by in-situ polymerization of aniline on silica gel template. Through the p-MC precursor, mesoporous carbon (MC) and hierarchical porous carbons (HPC) were fabricated to store sulfur. Afterward, the PANI coating on CNTs as additional conductive material was applied to the surface of HPC@S to prepare the HPC@S-PANi composite as shown in Fig. 9(b), which can be acted as an electronic bridge structure for gluing HPC particles of yolk-shell together to provide a “point-to-plane” electronic transmission mode in the place of “point-to-point”. In addition, PANI in the coating material could effectively retain polysulfide in the matrix to inhibit the shuttle effect and enhance the stability of the electrode. The HPC@S-PANi cathode could sustain a specific capacity of 494.5 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 2 A.g−1. A new type of spring-like multi-layer nanowires was reported by Liu's group [93], and they coated the sulfur on the surface of helix-structured SiO2@hydrogel nanowires. The bottom layer of SiO2 nanowires provided helix-shaped and the second layer of carbon increased the surface roughness of SiO2, which was beneficial to the coating of PANI. Finally, the third layer of hydrogel PANI improved the conductivity of the electrode and enabled interaction with lithium polysulfides. The third type of form configuration (S/PANI/C)is that PANI is coated on the sulfur and then wrapped with carbon material. The PANI layer (thickness of 27.5 nm) formed on the surface of sulfur nanoparticles as the inner shell via the in-situ polymerization method. Then, rGO nanosheets were electrostatically assembled the outer shell, fabricating the rGO@PANI@S composite with double-shelled structure [94]. The rGO shell improved the conductivity and buffered the volume expansion of the cathode, and the PANI shell could confine sulfur particles and inhibit the lithium polysulfides by chemically bonding. What is more, it also can be acted as a bridge between S and rGO, leading to the cathode delivered a high initial capacity of 1482.7 mAh g−1 and maintained 812.1 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at a current of 100 mA g−1. Zhang et al. [95] did a similar study that they fabricated the S@PANI/GO composite (Fig. 9c). The functional groups on the GO surface could decrease the dissolution of lithium polysulfide in the electrolyte, thereby reducing its “shuttle effect”. Compared with S/GO cathode, the cathode delivered improved cycle stability and high-rate capability that showed a capacity of 641 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 1 C. Li et al. [96] synthesized the rGO nanosheets wrapped rice-like S:PANI composite. The PANI substrates had good electrical conductivity and formed a 3D conductive network associated with rGO nanosheets, contributing to the transfer of charge in electrode reactions. In addition to the above three form configurations, Yan et al. [97] reported a multilayered cathode through the layer-by-layer nano-assembly technique, which the positively charged S-polyaniline nanotubes (SPANI)–NH+ as the outermost layers deposited on the negatively charged S-carbon nanotubes polystyrene sulfonate (S-CNT-PSS-) by alternate adsorption. Both the SPANI and S-CNT layers played a conductive network role and provided the ionic conductive pathways, making the multilayered cathode could deliver a reversible capacity of 818 mAh g−1 even after 600 cycles at 0.3 C. In Li-Se batteries, the PANI was selected to coat on the Se/C composites by the oxidation polymerization method. Subsequently, the composites were encapsulated in graphene sheets, forming the PANI@Se/C-G composites. The uniform PANI layer not only restrained the dissolution of selenium, but also significantly improved the electrons/ions transport by combining with graphene, thereby improving the cycle stability and rate capability of the PANI@Se/C-G cathode, which could obtain a high capacity of 528.6 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at a high rate of 2 C (1 C = 675 mA g−1) [98]. The schematic illustration of the formation and long-term cycling performance of the cathode was presented in Fig. 9(d). In acidic solution, the surface of PANI shell is positively charged due to the presence of amino functional groups. Zhang et al. [99] took advantage of electrostatic interaction between the negatively charged hydrophilic graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets and the positively charged PANI shell in the acidic solution, fabricating the G@Se/PANI nanocomposite (Fig. 9e). The 1D structure of Se nanowire with a high length/diameter ratio not only adapted to the volume expansion without crushing but also provided a short diffusion length for Li+ insertion. And they also confirmed the PANI shell with a thickness of about 25 nm as a buffer through SEM test, inhibiting the destruction of the electrode structure during the charge and discharge process. Due to the synergistic effect of the high conductivity graphene sheet, unique PANI shell and the one-dimensional structure of selenium, the G@Se/PANI cathode can remain 567.1 mAh g−1 after 200th cycle at 0.2 C and have the high-rate capability of 510.9 mAh g−1 at 2 C. 3.2.2 S/Se with PPy and carbon materials When PPy and carbon materials are used together in the cathode of Li-S/Se, the PPy is mainly used as the coating layer through different polymerization methods to coat S/C composite or compounded with carbon materials to host sulfur. Like PANI, PPy as a coating layer has been coated on S/C composites, which plays a vital role in improving the conductivity of the electrode and prevents the penetration of lithium polysulfides into the electrolyte. PPy coated on the surface of MWCNTs/S composites has been researched by some groups [100–102]. For instance, Wang et al. [100] prepared the dual core–shell structured MWCNTs@S@PPy composite. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), the PANI coated on the MWCNTs@S composite surface. The inner MWCNTs acted as a conductive network for S and physically absorb lithium polysulfides to a certain extent, while the outermost elastic PPy layer could further improve the conductivity and stability of the composite during cycling. Besides coating on the MWCNTs@S composites, Yang et al. [103] used PPy to cover on the surface of acetylene black/sulfur (AB/S) composites as an outer layer, forming the core–shell structure for the AB/S@PPy composite (Fig. 10b). Compared with the pure AB/S cathode, the AB/S@PPy cathode was superior in electrochemical performance, which gave credit to the PPy coating layer that improving the electronic conductivity of the cathode and restraining the shuttle of lithium polysulfide. The PPy also was coated on the surface of CMK-8/sulfur by Wen’s group. Due to high specific surface area and large pore volume of CMK-8, as well as the excellent conductivity of PPy, the PPy@CMK-8/S cathode maintained 860 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C [104]. Pyrrole, as an N-doped source, easily adheres to the carbon skeleton through interaction [105]. Following the above strategies, Xie’s group [106] reported pyrrole modified graphene aerogel foam (Py-GF) to accommodate sulfur. The Py-GF was prepared firstly by a simple hydrothermal method, in which the pyrrole monomer could easily adhere to the surface and gallery of the graphene oxide sheet through H-bonding or π–π interaction. The pyrrole functional group mainly interacted with the insoluble lithium polysulfide to reduce its shuttle effect (Fig. 10c), and the graphene aerogel foam could accommodate a large amount of sulfur, leading to the PyGF@S cathode (with ~6.2 mg cm−2 sulfur loading) showed an initial specific capacity of 985.8mAh g−1 with a capacity retention of 81% after 100 cycles at 0.5 C. Nevertheless, compared to just use pyrrole monomer, most studies still tend to use PPy polymers. Tan et al. [107] coated PPy on the surface of graphene aerogel/sulfur (GA/S) composite through the electropolymerization method. The PPy coating layer suppressed the diffusion of lithium polysulfides and improved the cycle stability of the Li-S batteries. In addition, the 3D GA also can provide an interconnected conductive framework, causing the 3D GA/S/PPy cathode (with a sulfur content of 73 wt%) delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 1288 mAh g−1 and kept 1017 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 C. Li et al. [108] firstly prepared the 3D porous graphene hydrogel/sulfur and then coated the PPy layer via the vapor phase deposition (VD) method (Fig. 10d). During this method process, the 3D graphene hydrogel shrunk and formed the crumped structure, increasing the contact between sulfur and graphene, as well as shortening the transport distance of ions and electrons. As one of the carbon aerogels, the graphene hydrogel had the advantages of large surface area, interconnected conducting path and ultralow density. Besides, both the PPy layer and graphene can reduce lithium polysulfide shuttling by the chemical and physical interaction, respectively. The cathode could maintain a specific discharge capacity of 698 mAh g−1 with an ultra-slow 0.03% per cycle decay rate after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. In addition to being the above coating layer, PPy can also be used as the sulfur host. Rao et al. [109] used PPy nanofibers as the sulfur host and then wrapped up and down by the graphene oxide (GO) sheet as shown in Fig. 11 (a). Finally, reducing the GO sheet to prepare the free-standing G-PPy/S-G composite via a vacuum filtration approach. The role of PPy fiber was to support sulfur and connected two graphene sheets. And PPy fiber also improves the conductivity of the electrode and adsorb lithium polysulfides through chemical action. More importantly, the prepared PPy could also reduce the electrode volume changes because of its long-chain elastic structure. The double graphene layers provided a conductive network and restrained the diffusion of dissolved lithium polysulfides. In short, both the PPy and graphene layers improved the G-PPy/S-G cathode electrochemical performance. However, compared with just pure PPy alone to store sulfur in the S/C/PPy composite, the PPy and carbon materials together are more widely studied as sulfur-carrying composite materials. For instance, Lu et al. [110] decorated the carbon foam (CF) with PPy-modified rGO to obtain the window-like microstructure and 3D framework CF@rGO/PPy hybrids via facile pyrolysis and the freeze-drying method for Li-S cell (Fig. 11b), which were used as the sulfur host and current collector to form the CF@rGO/PPy-S freestanding electrodes. The PPy modified rGO (rGO/PPy) flakes guaranteed sufficient sulfur loading support and lithium polysulfide adsorption active sites. Furthermore, the integrity of the structure could be ensured because of the π-π interactions existed in rGO and PPy. As a result, the CF@rGO/PPy-S cathode showed a better electrochemical performance, which delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 1437 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and reach 95.6% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C. Gao’s group synthesized the ternary hierarchical nanostructure rGO/PPy/S composite. The pyrrole polymerized on the graphene oxide (GO) surface and then combined with sulfur along with the reduction of GO (Fig. 11c). The interlinked network and some chemical bonds help to adsorb sulfur and lithium polysulfides, while also improving the migration of electrons and ions and reducing the dissolution of lithium polysulfides. Consequently, the rGO/PPy/S could show a discharge capacity of 537.4 mAh g−1 and maintain 442.1 mAh g−1 after 400 cycles at 5C with more than 90% Coulombic efficiency [111]. Yu et al. [112] reported the tubular polypyrrole (T-PPy) wrapped on the biomass-derived carbon nanospheres (BCSs) derived from watermelon juice to fabricate the BCS@T-PPy composites as the sulfur host (Fig. 11d). The obtained BCSs were negatively charged due to rich oxygen-containing functional groups. Therefore, the pyrrole molecules were repelled around the surface of BCSs under the action of static electricity and were evenly dispersed under the action of ultrasound. Subsequently, with the addition of Fe3+, the pyrrole monomers polymerized from the starting site and formed the T-PPy composite. The obtained T-PPy composite had the synergistic effect with BCSs, leading to the cathode showed an initial capacity of 1143.6 mAh g−1 and maintained a capacity of 685.8 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at the current of 0.5 C. 3.2.3 S/Se with PTh or its derivatives and carbon materials When PTh and carbon materials are used together in the cathode of Li-S/Se batteries, besides the application of PTh for Li-S cells, its derivatives also have widely been applied in the cells. They are usually used as coating layers through different polymerization methods to coat C/S composite or compounded with carbon materials to carry sulfur. For instance, Li and co-workers [113] prepared the PTh coated the sulfur/Ketjen black composite by in situ polymerization method. The conductive PTh coating acted as an electron conductor, which promoted electrons to reach the surface of the sulfur layer through the polymer layer. In addition, its derivatives, such as PEDOT or PEDOT: PSS, were often reported for cathode together with carbon materials. Some groups added hydrochloric acid into sodium thiosulfate/PVP aqueous solution and reacted simply to synthesize spherical sulfur (S-sulfur) [114] (at room temperature) and diamond-shaped sulfur (D-sulfur) [115] (at 0 °C). And then, the EDOT monomer was polymerized on the surface of the sulfur particles to obtain a PEDOT shell layer, which respectively marked as S-sulfur and D-sulfur. The PEDOT layers not only promote the close contact between electrons and insulating sulfur but also inhibit the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfide. Besides, Yan’s group [115] selected SWCNTs as the conducting network to wrap the S-sulfur and D-sulfu to form flexible S-sulfur/SWCNTs and D-sulfur/SWCNTs cathodes. The D-sulfur/SWCNT cathode showed better performance than that of the S-sulfur/SWCNT cathode because D-sulfur had a higher PEDOT coating layer content and specific surface area than D-sulfur. The D-sulfur/SWCNT cathode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1520 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and maintained 75% of the initial capacity after 250 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 12 a). Porous carbon materials are favored by researchers due to high specific surface area and large pore capacity, which provides sufficient storage space for sulfur. Chen et al. [116] used the multi-chambered micro/mesoporous carbon nanocube (CNC) as the sulfur host. Afterward, coating the PEDOT layer on the CNC-S composites to prepare the P@CNC-S composites. The CNC had a high surface area (2425 m2/g) and a large pore volume (3.72 cm3/g), which provided sufficient storage space for sulfur and the physical barrier for lithium polysulfides, as well as had a buffer effect on volume changes. However, compared with the CNC-S cathode, the P@CNC-S cathode exhibited a better electrochemical performance because of the PEDOT coating layer, which has strong chemical bonding with the lithium polysulfides. Hence, with the dual protective effect, i.e., physical barriers (CNC) and chemical bonding (PEDOT) for lithium polysulfides, the prepared P@CNC-S composites delivered high rate capabilities of 842 mAh g−1 and 530 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 5 C and 10 C, respectively. Zeng et al. [117] coated PEDOT:PSS film on the S@DHPC (3D hierarchical porous carbon) composite to form trilayer cathode as shown in Fig. 12(b). The PEDOT:PSS coating layer played a role of preventing the lithium polysulfides from diffusing into the electrolyte. Due to the high porosity of DHPC matrix and the effect of three layers of PEDOT:PSS conductive film, the trilayer cathode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 846 mAh g−1 and retained 716 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 2 C. Graphene usually has been greatly reported and used together with three ECPs in the cathode materials of Li-S batteries due to its excellent performance. Wang et al. [118] made the nanostructured ECPs polymerized onto graphene oxide (GO) as the sulfur host to form the CP/GO@S ternary composites through a facile one-pot route (Fig. 12c). The prepared GO had the advantages of excellent intrinsic electric conductivity and abundant oxygen-containing functional groups, which could absorb lithium polysulfides through chemisorption. The incorporation of ECPs and GO provided excellent electronic and facilitated ion channels. Moreover, the CPs/GO binary composites had physical confinement and chemical absorption of lithium polysulfides. Thereout, they prepared the PANI/GO@S, PEDOT/GO@S and PANI@S cathodes. However, compared to the three cathodes, the electrochemical performance increased in the order of PANI@S < PANI/GO@S < PEDOT/GO@S. The PEDOT/GO@S cathode delivered a reversible discharge capacity of 800.2 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles (0.5C) with the sulfur content of 66.2 wt%. Wang's group [119] prepared the activated porous grapheme (aPG) to store S, forming the S@aPG composite. Subsequently, the PEDOT-PSS coated on the S@aPG composite surface as the coating layer to get the PEDOT/S@aPG composite. The aPG had a large surface and hierarchically porous structure, increasing the sulfur loading and providing better elemental sulfur contact. Nevertheless, because of conductive PEDOT-PSS layer not only effectively promoted the transport of charge, but also improved the reaction kinetics of Li-S batteries and established a barrier to prevent the dissolution of lithium polysulfide. The PEDOT/S@aPG cathode exhibited better electrochemical performance than S@aPG cathode. Xiao et al. [120] adopted the PEDOT:PSS mainly to reduce graphene oxide that used to sulfur growth because of sufficient nucleation sites. Due to the π-π interaction between rigid PEDOT and 2D graphene, the PEDOT:PSS was coated tightly on the surface of S-rGO (SG) to form the sandwich structure SGP composite via vacuum filtration. Both the PEDOT:PSS and graphene could improve the conductivity of cathode and entrap the dissoluble lithium polysulfide through chemical interaction, and this unique condensed structure also accommodated volume change during the cycle. Compared with the SG cathodes, the SGP cathodes had better electrochemical properties, which delivered an initial specific capacity of 1008 mAh g−1 and retained 806 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C. In addition, other carbon materials have also been studied. Gong et al. [121] chose the carbon black with abundant nanopores (BP) as the sulfur host and then encapsulated them into the PEDOT:PSS layer to form the PEDOT@S/BP composite. The BP had strong absorption of sulfur and alleviated the expansion of the cathode during the cycle. In comparison, the PEDOT@S/BP cathode had a good electrochemical performance because of the PEDOT:PSS layer, which facilitated electron transport and effectively prevented lithium polysulfide diffusion. He et al. [122] coated the PEDOT/PSS layer on the carbon fibers/sulfur (CF/S), fabricating the coaxial three-layered structure CF/S/PEDOT composite (Fig. 12d). The prepared CFs provided a 3D conductive frame and facilitated the transport of electrons and ions through the electrode. The surface coating PEDOT:PSS was a flexible buffer layer and barrier, which could not only inhibit the outward diffusion of lithium polysulfide, but also buffer the mechanical stress. Compared with the CF/S cathode, the CF/S/PEDOT cathode had high Coulomb efficiency and good cycle stability, which showed an initial charge capacity of 1272 mAh g−1 and retained a high capacity of 807 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 C. There are also some researches that about PEDOT:PSS coated S/C composites just as the additives for cathode. For instance, Raulo et al. [123] adopted vertical co-axial electrospinning technology to fabricate nanofibers are composed of in-situ grown sulfur particles embedded in a porous polyacrylonitrile shell, and then the nanofibers were coated with PEDOT:PSS (Fig. 12e). The main function of PEDOT: PSS coating was to increase the conductivity of the electrode and give a lithium polysulfide fixed-site through the polar interaction of its electron-rich functional group (thiophene) with the lithium polysulfide. The cathode using PEDOT-S@PAN flexible fibers as additives can not only immobilize the lithium polysulfide to reduce their “shuttle effect”, but also inhibit the volume change during battery cycling, which led to the batteries used the S/C/PEDOT-S@PAN cathode (5 wt% additives) still had a capacity retention rate of about 41% of its initial capacity after 500 cycles at a current rate of 0.5 C. 3.3 S/Se with ECPs and polar materials In recent years, polar materials (PMs) have received extensive attention due to their strong chemical bonds to lithium polysulfide (polyselenide). Polar metal oxides have been widely used in the modification of cathode materials for Li-S/Se batteries due to their advantages such as adsorbing lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) [124], improving the mutual conversion ability between lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) and S (Se) and forming 3D nanometer structure, etc. However, their low conductivity, slow reaction rate and unstable long-term cycling characteristics limited their practicability [125]. Polar metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have ultra-high porosity, controllable pore size, highly ordered structure and strong chemical bonds with lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) but not rather good conductivity. Moreover, compared with polar materials, ECPs have weaker adsorption of lithium polysulfides (polyselenide). Therefore, researchers faced up to the shortcomings of ECPs and PMs, and gave full play to their advantages, using ECPs and PM together in Li-S/Se batteries to implement the excellent adsorption force and conductivity of the electrode. 3.3.1 S/Se with PANI and polar materials In Li-S batteries, MnO2-based nanocomposites have attracted particular attention due to its uniform structure and large surface area [126]. In addition, the prepared MnO2 has hydrophilic Mn-O and surface hydroxyl groups, which could enhance the interaction between MnO2 and sulfur and further combine with lithium polysulfide anions. However, its conductivity needs to be improved. Hence, Zhang et al. [125] prepared the PANI-MnO2composite as the sulfur host, in which the PANI layer wrapped the MnO2 nanoparticles. The in-situ PANI modification not only reduced the size of MnO2 nanoparticles but also facilitated the formation of a three-dimensional layered porous network, which promoted to shorten the electron transport paths and restrain the volume changes. Besides, the 3D porous network anchored the sulfur species in the host and the MnO2 nanoparticles had a strong interaction with lithium polysulfides, leading to the PANI-MnO2-S cathode showed an initial discharge capacity of 1275 mAh g−1 and maintained a stable reversible capacity of 1195 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles (0.5 C). TiO2 also has hydrophilic Ti-O groups and surface hydroxyl groups but low conductivity, Cheng et al. [127] used the PANI hydrogel coated on the surface of bowl-shaped hollow TiO2 to stockpile the sulfur, getting the TiO2@PANI@S composites as shown in Fig. 13 (a). The conductive PANI array not only improved the conductivity of the composite, but also provided a large surface area for sulfur loading. The TiO2 could effectively adsorb polysulfide and enhance the cycle stability. Moreover, this bowl-shaped hemispherical structure provided a larger surface to coat the secondary material and also had space for the volume change of sulfur, so that the TiO2@PANI@S cathode delivered an excellent reversible capacity of 1058 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C with 99.8% Coulombic efficiency, and its capacity also kept stable after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. In the Li-Se batteries, the PANI coated Zr-MOFs (UIO-67) encapsulated active Se composites (UIO-67@Se@PANI) was reported by Rui’s group [128]. The illustration of synthesis process and TEM images of the UIO-67@Se@PANI composite were presented in Fig. 13(b). The unsaturated sites on the UIO-67 carrier inhibited the dissolution of active Se, while the PANI layer on the surface of the UIO-67 carrier hindered the outward dissolution of lithium polyselenide. In addition, the PANI coating also improved the conductivity of the entire electrode material, making the cathode have better cycle stability and resulting in the UIO-67@Se@PANI cathode maintained a stable capacity of 248.3, 203.1 and 167.6 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C, 2 C and 5 C, respectively. 3.3.2 S/Se with PPy and polar materials Due to the poor wettability of PPy to lithium polysulfide, there is poor contact between them, so that the interaction efficiency between them is low and the interface impedance is high. Given the defect of PPy and its excellent conductivity, researchers have introduced metal oxides to make PPy have long-term development. Zhang et al. [129] polymerized the pyrrole on the surface of MnO2 nanowires, wherein MnO2 nanowires were served as template and chemical oxidization initiator to obtain the PPy-MnO2 coaxial nanotubes. After that, the sulfur was infiltrated into the nanotube to form the S/PPy-MnO2 ternary composite as shown in Fig. 13(c). The PPy layer provided conductive frameworks and MnO2 nanowires also had the excellent ability of lithium polysulfide capture, resulting in the S/PPy-MnO2 electrodes (70 wt% of S and 5 wt% of MnO2) just had a 0.07% per cycle decay rate along with 500 cycles at 1 C with ~98.6% stable Coulombic efficiency. Recently, Du et al. [130] did similar work, and they used the same synthetic method to get the MnO2-PPy-S cathode with sulfur mass loading of 63.5%, which showed an excellent rate capability at 470 mAh/g at the current density of 3 C. Li et al. [131] chose the porous hollow spheres MnO2 as the sulfur host to form the yolk-shelled MnO2@S composite via the liquid-phase method and then coated PPy on the MnO2@S surface to obtain the PPy@MnO2@S composite. Because MnO2 had chemical bonding with lithium polysulfides and the outer PPy also improved the electronic conductivity and lithium ions transport. Furthermore, the dual-shell structure offered two barrier restrictions for lithium polysulfides, and the PPy@MnO2@S cathode delivered superior electrochemical performance, which could retain a capacity of 704.1 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 C with sulfur loading of 3.3 mg cm−2. In the previous content, we mentioned that PPy with tubular structure can be synthesized by the self-degradation method. Recently, Wu et al. [132] firstly synthesized the tubular PPy and then embedded Co3O4 hollow microspheres into the conductive network of PPy nanotubes as a sulfur host. Finally, sulfur not only penetrated into the interior of Co3O4 hollow microspheres but also coated on the surface of PPy nanotubes. The schematic diagram of the fabrication process and the SEM and TEM images of S@Co3O4/PPy composite were presented in Fig. 13(d), which displayed that the PPy nanotubes and the hollow Co3O4 microspheres both can furnish specific surface area for active sulfur and restrain volumetric expansion. The hollow Co3O4 microspheres provided efficient accommodation space for releasing the volumetric expansion and had strong adsorption interaction of lithium polysulfides. Besides, PPy nanotubes furnished specific surface area for active sulfur and improved the conductivity of the cathode. The S@Co3O4 and S@Co3O4/PPy cathode showed an initial discharge specific capacity of 909.2 and 1094.9 mAh g−1, respectively, and maintained a capacity of 150.1 and 370.6 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C, respectively. Wei et al. [133] anchored the tin oxides (SnO2) nanoparticles onto the tubular PPy (T-PPy) surface and then sulfur deposited on them formed the S/(T-PPy)@SnO2 composite. Because of the chemical bond between SnO2 and lithium polysulfides, the hierarchically porous SnO2 was mainly used as an effective lithium polysulfide trap to reduce their “shuttle effect”.
