As a conductive network, the T-PPy nanotubes not only improved the conductivity of the cathode but also adapted to the vast volume expansion of the cathode during the cycle process, while relatively limited the diffusion of lithium polysulfide. The synergistic effect of T-PPy and SnO2 enhanced the S/(T-PPy)@SnO2 cathode electrochemical performance, showing the decay rate per cycle was only 0.05% along with 500 cycles at 1 C and excellent rate performance of 383.7 mAh/g even at 5 C. A kind of 3D macroporous polypyrrole (3DOMPPy) was prepared with silica sphere nano-arrays as template by Zhao’s group [134]. The ultrafine ZnO nanocrystals were chosen to decorate on the surface of 3DOMPPy by in-situ solution growth, and then they used as the sulfur host to synthesize the S-3DOMPPy@ZnO composite by hydrothermal method (Fig. 13e). The applied ZnO had the chemical adsorption of lithium polysulfide due to the Li-O bonds. Moreover, as a sulfur reservoir, the prepared 3DOMPPy had a physical adsorption effect on lithium polysulfide due to its 3D structure. And it also provided a continuous electron transmission channel due to its excellent conductivity. The synergetic effect between 3DOMPPy and ZnO facilitated the S-3DOMPPy@ZnO cathode to exhibit an initial discharge capacity of 1053.2 mAh g−1 and maintained a capacity of 794.5 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.1 C. The PPy coated on the surface of TiO2 nanotube arrays (NTs) [135] and porous TiO2 spheres [136] as sulfur hosts for cathode were also reported. These two different structures of TiO2 can provide a large specific surface area for sulfur reservoir and an effective pathway for electrons transport, as well as effectively absorb lithium polysulfide to some extent. The synergistic effects of TiO2 and PPy improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In the PPy with the metal oxides mentioned above (Co3O4, SnO2, ZnO andTiO2) formed the PPy/MO composites, the PPy and metal oxides jointly were served as the storage of sulfur, and the polar metal oxides mainly played the role of adsorbing lithium polysulfide, while PPy mainly played the role of improving the conductivity of the electrode. However, researchers also reported that PPy coated on the metal oxides/sulfur surface as the coating layer. Xu et al. [137] synthesized the S/Al2O3/PPy ternary composite via in-situ chemical polymerization. The prepared Al2O3 and PPy both have the adsorption of dissolved lithium polysulfides. What is more, the used PPy can be acted as a conductive and flexible additive to accelerate electron transmission. The obtained S/Al2O3 and S/Al2O3/PPy cathode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 988 and 1088 mAh g−1, respectively, and maintained 482 and 730 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles (200 mA g−1), respectively. In addition to metal oxides, Deng's group reported the PPy encapsulation of three kinds of MOFs/S materials [138]. They firstly synthesized three kinds of MOFs i.e. MIL-53, MIL-101 and PCN-224, and then sulfur was impregnated into the pores of MOF and finally encapsulated with PPy layer as shown in Fig. 14 (a). Three different MOFs materials had different dimensions and pore structures, and they elucidated the key role of ions diffusion in high rate performance by comparing PPy-MOF structures with various pore geometries. Furthermore, the PCN-224 with cross-linked pores and tunnels stands out among the three MOFs. The excellent conductivity provided by PPy and the fine geometric structure of PCN-224 combined to make the PPy encapsulated PCN-224/S cathode show a high capacity of 670 and 440 mAh g−1 even at a high rate (10.0 C) after 200 and 1000 cycles, respectively. The ZIF-67, as a popular MOF material, has a rhombohedral dodecahedron structure and Co ions, which are advantageous to adsorb lithium polysulfide. Lately, Gao et al. [139] and Yang et al. [140] selected the ZIF-67 to mix with KMnO4 and thioacetamide, respectively, obtaining the hollow cobalt manganate (CoMn2O4) and S, Co co-doped carbon nanocages (SCC) as the sulfur host, respectively. Based on the above experiment, pyrrole monomers were polymerized on the surface of CoMn2O4/S and SCC formed the coating layers, which improved the electron transfer of electrodes. As an ion exchanger and catalyst carrier, α-ZrP with a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure is also used in the sulfur host material because of prominent lithium-ion transportation and storage capabilities, whereas, it has poor conductivity. In consequence, Liu et al. [141] synthesized α-ZrP/PPy material via a facile exfoliated-stacked method and then sulfur was deposited into the interlayer. The α-ZrP nanosheets could capture lithium polysulfides and catalyze the conversion reaction of lithium polysulfides (Fig. 14b). Meanwhile, the PPy conductive network could help to improve electron transport. The unique 2D sandwich-like structure of α-ZrP/PPy material was in favor of accommodating the volume expansion of cathode during the discharge process and be acted as a physical encapsulation to inhibit the spread of LiPSs diffusing, resulting in the α-ZrP/PPy@S cathode delivers a highly reversible capacity of 727.2 mAh g−1 even at 5 C. 3.3.3 S/Se with PEDOT or PEDOT:PSS and polar materials At present, compared with PTh and PMs work together on the sulfur cathode, PTh’s derivative i.e. PEDOT has more studies. For instance, Yan et al. [142] chose the PEDOT as the coating layer on the surface of sulfur nanoparticles and anchored amorphous MnO2 onto S@PEDOT surface via a simple method to form the core–shell S@PEDOT/MnO2 nanospheres. Both the PEDOT and MnO2 layers can be served as an effective physical barrier and confined the sulfur/lithium polysulfides. Furthermore, they also improved the wettability of the electrolyte to the electrode material and enhanced the reaction kinetics, leading to the cathode delivered a capacity of 827 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2C. Luan et al. [143] prepared PEDOT/TiO2/S composites as the cathode via the traditional melt diffusion method. Compared with the TiO2/S cathode, the 15Ti-PEDOT/S (15 wt% TiO2) cathode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1110 mAh g−1 and maintained the reversible capacity of 532.1 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (1C). This excellent electrochemical performance was mainly due to the high conductivity of PEDOT, which facilitated the transport of electrons and lithium ions to/from the cathode materials. Jin et al. [144] selected MIL-101(Cr) as a sulfur host to form the MIL-101(Cr)/S composite after that biomolecule-doped PEDOT:PSS coated on it to form the biomolecule-doped PEDOT:PSS/Cr-MIL-101/sulfur(BPCS) composite. The MIL-101(Cr) had a 5000 m2 g−1 surface area and pore volume (>1.6 cm3 g−1) as a core structure. Under the dual role of MIL-101(Cr) and biomolecule-doped PEDOT:PSS, the multi-core–shell BPCS cathode for Li-S batteries showed improved discharge capacity. Su et al. [145] reported one kind of Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) nearly equal to MOF, sodium iron cyanide (Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6]), to store sulfur and then coated PEDOT layer to get the S@Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6]@PEDOT composite. The PBAs are typical porous coordination polymer materials based on the Lewis acid-base bonding interaction, which reduced the diffusion of lithium polysulfides outside the cathode and minimized the shuttling effect. Moreover, the coating layer PEDOT not only improved the conductivity of the cathode but also trapped the lithium polysulfides as shown in Fig. 15 (a). Hence, both the S@Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6] and S@Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6]@PEDOT composite respectively delivered a capacity of 763 and 1101 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1C, showing the importance of PEDOT coating layer. The N-doped carbon matrix had a chemical affinity for lithium polysulfide due to Li-N bond, Tan et al. [146] used the zinc-based MOFs material (ZIF-8) as a synthetic mesoporous N-doped carbon precursor and placed them between the two layers of graphene for carbonization, whereafter, loading the sulfur and coated the PEDOT to form the self-assembly sandwiches P@rGO/ZIF-8(C)-S composite as shown in Fig. 15(b). The graphene can be acted as the support layers to avoid the destruction of the ZIF-8-derived carbon framework after carbonization and provide a conductive network. The ZIF-8(C) had high specific surface area and N-containing functional groups, which offered the chemisorption with lithium polysulfides. Moreover, the PEDOT coating improved the conductivity of the electrode. Therefore, the P@rGO/ZIF-8(C)-S cathode showed excellent cycling stability. 3.4 S/Se with ECPs-based composite and other materials In addition to the carbon materials and polar materials mentioned above, the use of ECPs mixed in pairs or with other materials has also been studied in some papers. For example, polyaniline-co-polypyrrole (PANI-PPy) hollow spheres were synthesized through copolymerization and followed by carbonizing them to obtain a kind of hollow carbon nanospheres (HCNs), which had ultra-high surface area and uniform nano-morphology was suitable as a carbon material for sulfur storage [147]. Subsequently, Zeng et al. [148] based on this experiment, added CO2 activation step to improve the specific surface area of carbon, and activation time could easily control the cavity diameter and wall thickness of the HCNs. After their experimental exploration, the HCNs-AC60/S-60 (CO2 activation of 60 min, 60% sulfur content) with ultrahigh surface areas (2274 m2 g−1) and the large pore volume (1.6 cm3 g−1) were the most superior among the others HCNs/S composites. The cathode delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1401 mAh g−1 and maintained 626 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2C. Yue et al. [149] also have brought forward HCNs, which firstly synthesized the PANi-PPy nanoparticles by the copolymerization method and then carbonized the nanoparticles as the sulfur host. Different from the first two experimental studies, they applied SiO2 nanoparticles impregnated with the PANi-PPy precursor as pore-forming particles and then covered a layer of MnO2 layer on the S/HCN composites. Zhang et al. [150] synthesized the 3D hybrid structure composite (abbreviated as NCF/CNT/PEDOT@S). The schematic of the structure and fabrication process of the flexible binder-free NCF/CNT/PEDOT@S and NCF/CNT@S electrodes was shown in Fig. 15(c). The cathode showed a high capacity even with a high sulfur loading, which gave credit to the rich N content of NCF, the high conductivity and prominent mechanical properties of CNT, and the physical confinement for lithium polysulfides and maintained structural stability of PEDOT. ECPs have excellent electrical conductivity but poor ionic conductivity. However, ionic-electronic conducting composite can be obtained by adding ionic conducting polymer. Sen et al. [151] synthesized the ionic-electronic conducting S-MIEC composites, which used polyethylene glycol (PEG) based surfactant tethered on ultra-fine sulfur nanoparticles and then wrapped with PANI. The combination of PEG and sulfur created a chemical gradient in the composite material, which adapted to the vast volume expansion of the sulfur particles during the cycle and facilitated different channels for ions. The PANI's role in the S-MIEC composites was to act as an effective, flexible trap for sulfur and lithium polysulfides and provide unique channels for electrons. Because of the incorporation of PEG and PAIN, the assembled Li-S batteries showed a stable capacity of nearly 900 mAh g−1 at a current rate of 1 C after 100 cycles. Lee’s et al. [152] presented the ionic-electronic conducting PEDOT-co-PEG polymer coated on the surface of sulfur particles as shown in Fig. 15(d), even if only 1 wt% of the polymer coating layer with average thickness of about 40 nm coated on the sulfur’s surface, and this dual conductive polymer coated sulfur cathode could show an outstanding discharge capacity of 1002 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. 3.5 Summary The above mainly summarizes the use of ECPs alone or their application combining with carbon materials and polar materials in cathodes of Li-S/Se batteries. The synthetic methods of ECPs mainly include solution polymerization, interfacial polymerization and template polymerization, whereas those methods have their own advantages and disadvantages. For instance, the template method process could obtain various shapes of ECPs/S composites according to the different templates. However, its application is limited due to the requirement to separate the template from prepared ECPs and the possibility of destroying the polymer structure or forming additional copolymer structures during the separation process. Although the chemical synthesis method in the solution is simple and easy to obtain, the ECPs prepared by this method is easy to agglomerate. Therefore, finding a novel method with saving energy, green and environmental protection and high efficiency is significant. In addition, it is worth mentioning that the template synthesis method provides a simple, efficient and highly controllable way for the design and synthesis of new ECPs nanostructures. However, the morphology of the obtained ECPs nanostructure largely depends on the monomer concentration, surfactant concentration and oxidant concentration. The oxidant concentration not only affects the structure of ECPs [44], but also impacts the distribution of sulfur on the surface of ECPs [45]. Therefore, controlling their concentration is the key to obtaining ECPs with different structures and a stable ECPs-S/Se cathode. The prepared ECPs in the Li-S/Se cathodes are mainly used as the covalent bond compound, coating layer, host material, porous carbon precursor and redox mediator to improve cathode conductivity, suppress shuttle effect and reduce volume expansion. When the ECPs directly act on the cathode alone, they are mainly used as coating layers to coat the surface of S/Se and as storage materials to store S/Se in different forms. Besides, selecting the ECPs or ECPs copolymer (e.g., PANI-PPy copolymer) as the porous carbon precursor has also been studied. The prepared porous carbon could obtain ultrahigh surface areas and the large pore volume porous carbon material under the action of high-temperature carbonization and gas activation, which lays the future development of the ECPs. The sulfur-rich copolymer, which contains ECPs (e.g., SPANI and S3BT copolymer), can be synthesized by co-pyrolysis or covalent grafting method, and those copolymers play a significant role in anchoring sulfur. Furthermore, the PANI containing quinonoid imine can also act as redox mediators to absorb lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) and speed up the redox reaction of Li-S/Se batteries. Even a small change in the chemical environment around nitrogen atoms would cause huge changes in the adsorption capacity, which makes it possible for us to explore more undiscovered nitrogen-containing functional groups to improve chemical reaction kinetics in the future. Although the original ECPs showed good performance when acting on Li-S/Se batteries' cathode alone, their inherent defects still hinder their further development. In this case, carbon materials and polar materials have been introduced to work together with ECPs in Li-S/Se batteries. In these ECPs/C-based S/Se cathodes, there are three types of form configurations among ECPs, carbon materials and S/Se. The one form configuration is ECPs coated on the S/C composite. In this form configuration, carbonaceous materials are open systems with a rigid conductive skeleton. When they are used as the carrier of elemental S/Se alone, they have limited adaptability to volume expansion during charging and discharging and limited binding capacity of the lithium polysulfide (polyselenide). Hence, after adding the flexible ECPs as a coating layer coated on the S/Se, the ECPs layer with flexible characteristics not only protects the structural integrity of the electrode, but also inhibits the outward dissolution of S/Se and lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), improving the electrochemical performance of the electrode during the reaction process. However, in this form configuration, the lithium-ion transmission is relatively blocked, and electrolyte permeability is reduced. The other form configuration is the ECPs grow on carbon materials and then they both act as the storage material to encapsulate S/Se. In this form configuration, the lithium-ion transmission is smooth and liquid electrolyte permeability is good. Nonetheless, because the physical barrier is reduced, the “shuttle effect” may lightly increase. The final form configuration is ECPs firstly coated on the S/Se surface and then wrapped with carbon materials. In this form configuration, ECPs not only serve to prevent direct contact between S/Se and electrolyte but also act as a direct bridge between S/Se and carbon materials. These two coating layers make S/Se have double protection, but at the same time, they may make the lithium-ion transport channel longer and the electrolyte less permeable. Polar metaloxides and metal–organic frameworks are the most commonly used polar materials in S/Se cathodes. They have strong chemical bonds with lithium polysulfide (polyselenide). However, their electrical conductivity needs to be improved. Hence, the role of ECPs is mainly to improve the electrode conductivity as sulfur host and coating layer in the ECPs/PM-based S/Se cathodes. We also summarized two works about the combination of ECPs and ionic conducting polymers (e.g., PEG) to obtain ionic-electronic conductive composites, which can solve the problem of low ion conductivity about ECPs. 4 Modified separators/interlayers Currently, commercial separators modified by ECPs are widely used in Li-S batteries, and the performances of assembled batteries have been significantly improved. Besides, as early as in 2012, the important concept of the“interlayer” was firstly proposed by Manthiram’s group [153]. Subsequently, various interlayers have been widely studied and reported for their advantages of simple preparation technology, large-scale production and effective resistance to the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfide/polyselenide, etc. However, as battery interlayer materials, it is necessary to meet the requirements of the excellent blocker of lithium polysulfide/polyselenide, strong liquid electrolyte adsorption, and effective promotion of lithium ions transmission. Interlayers could be mainly divided into cathodic interlayers and anodic interlayers [154]. The cathodic interlayers are mainly based on carbon materials due to their excellent mechanical properties, unique electrical properties, perfect thermal stability and high specific surface area, whereas non-polar carbon materials may lack strong chemical bonds with migrating lithium polysulfides. Compared with carbon materials, ECPs have stronger chemical bonds with lithium polysulfide/polyselenide, but pure ECPs coatings may require thicker coating layers, which may increase the weight of inactive materials [155]. Considering the above issues, ECPs usually mixed with carbon materials as modified separators/interlayers, which as an extra-current collector, could significantly shorten charge transfer resistance and restrain the notorious “shuttle effect” of dissolved lithium polysulfide/polyselenide. Besides used with carbon materials, the ECPs alone forms a film or grafted on hydrolyzed polyethylene [156] as an interlayer have also been studied. 4.1 PANI modified separators/interlayers The PANI prepared without a carrier is usually a powder that is difficult to use as an interlayer material alone. Therefore, a self-supporting material is required as a matrix mixed with PANI as the cathodic interlayer [157]. Multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) is usually used as self-supporting material for PANI as the interlayer due to its excellent performance. Archer with co-wokers [158] applied the termed Langmuir-Blodgett-Scooping (LBS) coating technology to obtain multifunctional MWCNT/Titania nanoparticles/PANI interlayer for Li-S batteries through layer-by-layer configuration method as shown in Fig. 16 (a). The thin layer coating of carbon nanotubes was an effective adhesion layer of PANI coating, and the porous 3D Titania nanoparticles (TiO2 NP) was presented on the PANI coating. They also studied the flexibility and toughness of the prepared laminated PANI separator membranes, and the results showed that the prepared interlayer had excellent strength and flexibility. Moreover, the physical barrier provided by MWCNT and the chemical adsorption from the PANI and TiO2 NP leaded to the Li-S battery with the separator exhibited high capacity and stable cycle performance at various discharge rates even though without LiNO3 additives in the electrolyte. Manthiram’s group [159] mixed the polyaniline nanofibers (PANiNF) with MWCNT as the hybrid coating coated on the Celgard membrane facing the cathode (Fig. 16b). The PANiNF and MWCNT both could block and trap the lithium polysulfides via chemical bonding and physical adsorbing, respectively. The hybrid coating also achieved the reactivation/reutilization of captured active materials. Furthermore, it has ultra-lightweight about just c.a. 0.01 mg.cm−2. The hybrid coating-functionalized separator used in the Li-S batteries delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 1020 mAh g−1 and maintained a capacity of 709 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. Taking advantage of the SO3 - groups, which are permeable to Li+ and repellent to S n 2− because of the coulombic interactions [155], Shi et al. [160] first synthesized the MWCNT/PANI powders and then sulfonated the PANI, getting the MWCNT/SPANI composite to coat on the Celgard membrane facing the cathode. The assembled Li-S batteries remained a reversible capacity of 913 mAh g−1 with the 81% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1. Given graphene oxide (GO) with excellent mechanical properties, the PANI was synthesized on the GO membrane’s surface via in-situ chemical oxidation polymerization, fabricating the PANI-GO film as the cathodic interlayer. The main purpose of the PANI-GO interlayer was to limit the dissolution of lithium polysulfide within the cathode area of the battery through physical barriers and chemical absorption. Besides, the PANI-GO, as a secondary current collector, improved electron transfer and reactivated dead “sulfur”. The initial specific capacity was 1261mAh g−1 and 1100 mAh g−1 with the capacity retention rate of 73.0% and 68.0% after 150 cycles at 0.5 C for the PANI-GO interlayer, GO interlayer, respectively[157]. Jung's group reported a highly uniform PANI film directly used as an interlayer [161]. They adopted the transfer printing method to make the highly uniform PANI layer coated onto the graphene oxide-sulfur (GO-S) cathode. A key advantage of the transfer printing method was that the thickness of the PANI layer and the heat treatment conditions were controllable without affecting the lower electrode. The PANI layer as the robust protection not only improved the conductivity of the electrode but also restrained volume changes. Moreover, it also can capture lithium polysulfides and suppress their “shuttle effect”. In addition to the methods and materials reported above, Tubtimkuna et al. [156] grafted PANI on the modified hydrolysed polyethylene (HyPE) separator by an amide coupling reaction between –COOH (HyPE) and imine –NQ (PANI) to get the dual functional interlayers/separators for the assembled Li-S batteries. The HyPE-PANI combined lithium polysulfide with amine groups in the PANI structure to effectively suppress their “shuttle effect”. Furthermore, the HyPE-PANI interlayers/separators with functionalized nitrogen group not only reduced the capacity fading, but also increased the specific capacity of Li-S batteries. In Li-Se batteries, recently, Lee et al. [162] added aniline monomers in the electrolyte to form a protective conductive ultrathin (≤10 nm) PANI layer on the Se/C surface through electrochemical polymerization treatment, as shown in Fig. 16(c). The electrochemical treatment (charge) was carried out by applying a constant current (10 µA) to the Se/C-Li battery. They confirmed the oxidation reaction by voltage-capacity profiles and linear scanning voltage (LSV), and concluded that Se and electrolyte had no side reaction, the only aniline was oxidized to 4.0 VLi+/Li to form the emeraldine PANi layer during the electrochemical treatment. On the one hand, the prepared PANi layer reduced the direct contact between the electrodes and the electrolytes, thereby inhibiting the dissolution of selenium/lithium polyselenide. On the other hand, it promoted contact between the particles and increased the conductivity of the Se electrode. In addition, the C-N bonds effectively trapped lithium polyselenide and the formation of delocalized polaron lattice in PANI by self-doping lithium salt was prepared to improve the ionic conductivity, leading to the treated Li-Se battery having 40% higher capacity retention than the untreated one. Furthermore, the treated battery could maintain a capacity of 1538 mAh/cm3, while the untreated battery shows no capacity at the same high rate (4 C). 4.2 PPy modified separators/interlayers Compared with PANI, the application of PPy film alone as the interlayers was more reported than PPy mixed with carbon materials. Wu et al. [163] studied the PPy-treated carbon paper interlayer, which improved the interlayer’s conductivity and decreased the battery’s resistance as well as increased the migration of Li+ because of the PPy’s hydrophilic property. The remaining studies about the PPy film were used alone as the interlayer. For instance, PPy was directly coated on the upper and lower surface of commercial separator (CS) via vapor-phase polymerization by Fu’s group [164], fabricating the PPy@CS dual-functional separators. Compared with pristine CS, the PPy@CS had the strong adsorption capacity of lithium polysulfides, good ability to inhibit the growth of Li dendrites, excellent thermal stability and lower interfacial charge-transfer resistance, owing to PPy’s flexibility, excellent conductivity and chemisorption of lithium polysulfides. Ma et al. [165] synthesized the tubular polypyrrole (T-PPy) to acquire the PPy nanotubes film (PNTF) after the vacuum filtration and drying processes, which was used as the cathodic interlayer (Fig. 16d). The interlayer could reduce the polarization of the battery and inhibit the shuttle effect during the charging/discharging process. Hence, compared with the Li-S batteries without the PNTF interlayer, the assembled Li-S batteries with PNTF interlayer had better electrochemical performance, which delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1102 mAh g−1 and retained a capacity of 712 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.5 C. In addition, for the purpose of comparing the effect of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and PPy-modified interlayer applied to Li-S batteries, as well as the effect of different morphologies of PPy-modified interlayer on Li-S batteries, they also prepared three kinds of modified Celgard 2320 separator, i.e., PPy nanowires modified, PPy nanotubes modified and rGO modified separator via vacuum filtration. The obtained PPy nanotubes and PPy nanowires were prepared by the self-degraded template method and chemical polymerization method, respectively. Comparatively speaking, the PPy modified separator revealed the smaller contact angle, lower polarization and stronger adsorption of lithium polysulfides than that of rGO modified separator, attributing to the H-based functional group and the porosity of PPy coating layer. Besides, from the thickness of the corrosion layer on the lithium anode side, they concluded that PPy nanotube (25 μm) modified separators were more suitable as interlayers than that of PPy nanowire (35 μm) [166]. Wang’s group [167] synthesized the PPy film and PPy nanofiber (black PPy powder) via electrodeposition and oxidative chemical polymerization. Sulfur was chemically deposited on the surface of PPy nanofiber, forming the S@PPy composite by the vacuum filtration. And then, the prepared S@PPy composite was coated on PPy film to fabricate PPy/S@PPy cathode. Besides, they also used the PPy nanofiber coated on the commercial separator to obtain PPy-separator (Fig. 16e). The PPy film’s rough surface was conducive to the adhesion of the active material and trap lithium polysulfides. Moreover, the PPy film could also decrease the volume expansion and maintain integrity because of its elastic properties. More importantly, the PPy coated layer served as a reservoir for capturing lithium polysulfides and an upper current collector for facilitating electron transfer, leading to the Li-S battery showed an initial discharge capacity of 1236 mAh g−1 and maintained a capacity of 1073 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C. Rarely used for oxidative electrochemical polymerization of ECPs in Li-S batteries was also reported by Osaka’s group [168]. They prepared the PPy film directly on the surface S/Ketjenblack cathode via oxidative electropolymerization in the three-electrode cells, wherein the film inhibited the penetration of lithium polysulfides into the electrolyte. When polymerizing at a high potential of 4.5 V, the TFSI- was incorporated into the film. However, adding LiTFSI to the polymerization solution had a more significant effect on the Li+ transport number of the prepared PPy film, which proved the importance of optimizing the polymerization conditions of PPy on the S/KB cathode. 4.3 PEDOT or PEDOT:PSS modified separators/interlayers Poly (3,4-dioxyethylene thiophene) (PEDOT) is one of the derivatives of PTh, which has many excellent properties. However, the insoluble properties of PEDOT limited its application in many aspects. The polystyrene sulfonic acid (PSS) is a water-soluble electrolyte, and introducing PSS into PEDOT to form the structure of PSS wrapped PEDOT could significantly promote the solubility in the solvent. The PEDOT:PSS film was also used as the cathodic interlayer due to its excellent film-forming performance and the negatively charged SO3 - group in the PSS, which can be acted as an electrostatic shield against the soluble lithium polysulfide through coulomb mutual exclusion. Abbas et al. [169] made full use of the PEDOT:PSS to spray-coating onto the Celgard 2500 separator to form the bifunctional separator, which not only effectively inhibited the shuttle of lithium polysulfide but also changed the hydrophobicity of membrane surface to hydrophilicity, thus improving the wettability and electrolyte intake. The SO3 - group with a negative charge in PSS had an electrostatic shielding effect on soluble lithium polysulfide through Coulomb repulsion. In addition, the PEDOT offered chemical interactions with insoluble polysulfides (Li2S and Li2S2). Theoretical mechanism of the Li-S battery featuring a PEDOT:PSS-coated separator was presented in Fig. 16(f). The bifunctional separator gave the battery excellent cycling performance with decay rates as low as 0.0364% per cycle over 1000 cycles. For improving the conductivity of the electrode, carbon nanotube and carbon black were introduced as the interlayers with PEDOT:PSS. Wang et al. [170] prepared the PEDOT:PSS-carbon nanotube (CNT) film as the interlayer via vacuum filtration and H2SO4 treatment as shown in Fig. 16(g). The H2SO4 treatment significantly improved the PEDOT:PSS-CNT film conductivity (930 S.cm−1), which was better than that of the CNT film conductivity (3 S.cm−1). The porosity of CNTs provided the porous transmission channel and promoted the rapid diffusion of lithium ions. The PEDOT:PSS not only served as a soft buffer for lithium polysulfide reservoirs, but also inhibited the “shuttle effect” through chemical absorption. Compared with pure PEDOT:PSS and CNT interlayers, the PEDOT:PSS-CNT interlayer showed better electrochemical performances because of the synergistic effect of CNT and PEDOT: PSS. Yi et al. [171] fabricated the bi-functional carbon black (CB)/PEDOT:PSS interlayer by a simple one-step physical method, in which the CB/PEDOT: PSS was blade-coated on the side of the Celgard separator facing the cathode side. The obtained PEDOT: PSS played a crucial role in the bi-functional CB/PEDOT:PSS interlayer because the PEDOT had a strong interaction with soluble lithium polysulfides and the SO3 - functional group in PSS provided a hopping channel for lithium ions, which can facilitate redox. Owing to the physical absorption of CB and chemical absorption of PEDOT:PSS, the bi-functional separator not only served as a secondary current collector but also as an effective lithium polysulfide trap. In addition, the chemical kinetics of modified separators can be promoted by enhancing lithium-ion diffusion, resulting in the Li-S battery (1.6 mg.cm−1 sulfur loading) with this CB/PEDOT:PSS modified separator had an initial capacity of 1315 mAh g−1 at 0.2C and maintained 956 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles. Song et al. [172] added the EDOT monomer into the electrolytes to form the PEDOT layer on the CMK-3/S cathode surface via electro-oxidative polymerization of EDOT. The PEDOT layer could inhibit lithium polysulfide shuttle and reduce electrolyte decomposition, significantly improving the capacity retention and cycling stability compared with uncoated PEDOT layer cathode. 4.4 Summary The conductivity of ECPs determines that they can be used as interlayers or coating layer not directly apply for the total separators. Since PANI prepared without a carrier is usually a powder, it usually uses various carbon materials as a carrier to act on the separators/interlayers. As for PPy, it often easily acquires PPy nanotubes film through vacuum filtration to be used as an interlayer alone. PEDOT:PSS has better film-forming property than PEDOT, but they both can be acted as the membrane themself or are mixed with carbon material to make a film as an interlayer or coat on the commercial separator. We noticed that all the three ECPs had been reported to synthesize ECPs interlayers through electrochemical polymerization to coated on the surface of cathodes. The electrochemical polymerization method is easy to operate, in which polymerization and doping processes are carried out at the same time. What is more, the oxidation state and thickness of the polyaniline film could be controlled by changing the polymerization potential and electric quantity. However, in this method, the oxidation potential of the monomer is generally higher than the reversible redox potential of the obtained polymer, resulting in the overoxidation of the polymer chain may occur during the polymerization process. Furthermore, the selectivity of the monomer polymerization active center is poor. That is why they are easy to polymerize the film but rarely are reported. 5 Conductive binders Binder is one of the core materials of auxiliary components in Li-S/Se batteries and is essential in the process of electrode fabrication, which needs to have excellent bonding performance to bond the active electrode material, the conductive agent and the current collector. For the Li-S/Se batteries system, binder plays a critical role in stabilizing the cathode structure, improving the sulfur loading and sulfur utilization, and enhancing cyclic stability [173]. Currently, commonly used binders in Li-S/Se batteries are mainly PVDF (polyvinylidene fluoride), PEO (polyethylene oxide) and PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene) and so on. Nevertheless, these binders still have many shortcomings. For instance, their insulation has little effect on improving the conductivity of the cathode and they have a weak affinity for lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), so they cannot effectively solve the shuttle problem. Besides, they cannot buffer massive volume changes during the discharge/charge cycle process to maintain the structural integrity of the cathode because they have linear polymer chains and weaker interchain interactions, which shows that it is necessary to introduce other functional binders. The ECPs have been used in the researches of Li-S/Se batteries binders on account of their excellent conductivities and high molecular polarities, which limits the diffusion of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) and promotes the fast transfer of electrons. 5.1 ECPs binders Liu’s group reported the PEDOT as binder was used in the sulfur electrode of Li-S [174]. The electrochemical performance showed that the battery with PEDOT binder had lower initial capacity than that of the PVDF but had a higher capacity retention rate. The phenomenon can be explained that when used the cathode with non-conductive PVDF binders, the volume change pushed the sulfur particles away from the conductive carbon network during the charging/discharging process, causing some sulfur particles to lose their activity. However, the conducting PEDOT binder adhered to sulfur, and the sulfur particles can conduct electricity even if they are disconnected from the conductive carbon network. Wang et al. [175] used the PEDOT:PSS as the conductive binders to evenly mix with graphene, which can be acted as an outer layer coated on the polyvinylpyrrolidone-coated sulfur microspheres (PVPS) to form the free-standing PVPS/PED@RGO cathode. Compared with the PVPS@RGO and PVPS/PED@RGO cathode, the results of the two cathode’s rate performance clearly showed that the addition of PEDOT-PSS could further enhance the electrochemical kinetics of the electrode because of the addition of PEDOT-PSS improved the adhesion of PVPS to the graphene surface, the overall conductivity of the electrode and the charge transport. In order to improve the application of PEDOT:PSS binder in cathode capacity and cycle stability, Yan et al. [176] synthesized a 3D network PEDOT:PSS-Mg2+ binder i.e. Mg(NO3)2 reacting with the -SO2OH group of PSS to produce -SO2O-Mg-O-SO2- linkage (Fig. 17 a). Compared with other conventional binders such as PVDF binder, the PEDOT:PSS-Mg2+ binder just needed water as a solvent and avoided the use of toxic organic solvents. The prepared binder could suppress the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides because of the sulfur and oxygen atoms in the PEDOT:PSS. Moreover, this binder, with the high electrical conductivity and 3D network structure, increased conduction and charge transfer reactions and buffer the dramatic volume changes, leading to the cathode using this binder exhibited a high initial capacity of 1097 mAh g−1 and capacity retention of 74% after 250 cycles at 0.5C. Pan et al. [177] reported a water-soluble mixed binder for cathodes through just physically mixing polyacrylic acid (PAA) and PEDOT:PSS. The PAA improved the solvent system of the sulfur cathode and facilitated the transfer of lithium ions, and the PEDOT:PSS had the advantages of good conductivity and enhanced affinity for lithium polysulfide in the mixed binder. The schematic diagram of the sulfur cathodes with different binders was presented in Fig. 17(b), and the experimental results showed that the combination of these two binders for Li-S batteries presented better electrochemical performance than any single-component binder. The application of PPy and PANI in binders had also been reported in small quantities. Milroy et al. [178] prepared the active binder (PPyPU) comprised of polypyrrole (PPy) and polyurethane (PU) for Li-S electrodes (Fig. 17c). The conductive PPy could limit the migration of lithium polysulfides through chemical reactions and the elastomeric PU could adapt to the violent volume expansion of sulfur. Hence, the PPyPU binder reduced activation overpotential and enhanced electrode performance. Nonetheless, matrix polymers such as PU or PAA were insulated, and inevitably reducing the electrical conductivity of the binders. Consequently, Gao et al. [179] synthesized the sulfuric acid doped PANI as the cathode’s binder, which just liked the “cobweb” sustaining the whole electrode electrical integrity as shown in Fig. 17(d). In addition to the necessary adhesion function, the binder could also capture lithium polysulfide to reduce the impact of the shuttle effect and provide good conductivity. Compared with the most commonly used PVDF binder, the sulfuric acid doped polyaniline binder had a specific capacity increased by more than 58%. It was reported that using sodium alginate as a binder instead of PVDF could obtain better sulfur-based cathode to enhance electrochemical performance [180]. In addition, the presence of COOH/OH groups in the sodium alginate binder could also effectively anchor the lithium polysulfide to inhibit their dissolution in the electrolyte. Consequently, the in-situ polyaniline/sodium-alginate binder to 3D interconnect the rGO/Mn3O4/S nanocomposites was reported by Ghosh’s group [181]. The main function of the in-situ polyaniline/sodium-alginate binder was to bond various materials of the electrodes, which can be acted as a structural buffer effectively adapt to the huge volume changes caused by the insertion/extraction of Li+ during the cycle, and be regarded as a continuous conductive matrix throughout the electrode to accelerate the ions/electrons conductivity (Fig. 17e). 5.2 Summary This chapter mainly summarizes the application of ECPs in binders, and their conductivity and special functional groups render them can not only improve the conductivity of the electrode but also adsorb lithium polysulfides. However, when ECPs used alone as a binder, the assembled battery's performance is often unsatisfactory. For instance, the PEDOT:PSS has the weak electrolyte absorption ability that is not conducive to lithium-ion transmission. Meanwhile, the PEDOT:PSS has strong film-forming properties, resulting in the agglomeration of sulfur materials and the non-uniform deposition of Li2S2/Li2S [177]. In addition, the brittleness of PPy [178] and PANI [179] makes it difficult for them to adapt to the severe volume expansion of sulfur during discharge, and their compact layer would hinder ions transportation. Therefore, in order to make ECPs widely used in binders, it is necessary for us to modify ECPs or to incorporate other functional binders (such as quaternized polymer binder [182] and redox-mediating polymer binder [183]) by physical mixing and chemical treatment. 6 Working mechanisms 6.1 Improve conductivity Electrical conductivity is an important index to improve electron conduction rate and electrochemical reaction kinetics in Li-S/Se batteries. We know that when the ECPs under the action of the electric field, the carriers (holes or free electrons) follow the polymer molecules chain migration or inter-chain leaping form a macroscopic current and conduct conduction. Meanwhile, we can significantly improve their conductivities through doping techniques, such as chemical doping, electrochemical doping, acid-base doping and light excitation doping. Hence, the application of ECPs to the S/Se cathodes or modified separators/interlayers and binders can greatly improve the electronic conductivity of the battery and thus accelerate the Li-S/Se batteries reaction processes. 6.2 Physical confinement Physical confinement is usually using porous media or building external physical barriers to minimize the escape of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) by physical adsorption. The application of nanotubes and hollow sphere structure ECPs to seal S/Se in the inner cavity as physical barriers have an outstanding confinement role for active materials, which can also accommodate large volume expansion and prevent the outward diffusion of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) from inhibiting their “shuttle effect”. Moreover, the porous carbons obtained by using ECPs as precursors can reduce S/Se or lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) outward diffusion by physical adsorption. Besides, the ternary composite of different structures formed by ECPs and carbon materials or polar materials have a double physical confinement function. ECPs, either alone or mixed with carbon materials to modify the separators or as interlayers, can also serve as physical barriers to further reduce the lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) shuttling. In future research, we can also design different novel porous structures to simultaneously encapsulate S/Se, suppress the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites. 6.3 Chemical adsorption Apart from physical adsorption, ECPs are also characterized by their chemical adsorption to lithium polysulfides (polyselenides). Relatively speaking, chemical adsorption can significantly inhibit the shuttle of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides). Since ECPs contain special functional groups such as N, S, O, which can provide extra lone pair electrons to coordinate with the electron acceptor of lithium ions, they have a strong chemical adsorption effect on lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) [184]. Moreover, through co-pyrolysis or covalent grafting method, ECPs can form a copolymer with S/Se by a covalent bond, which can further inhibit the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) to a certain extent. 6.4 Catalyst redox Early studies have shown that the diffusion of lithium ions can be used as a suitable descriptor for evaluating the kinetics of polysulfide (polyselenides) conversion, and the rapid lithium-ion diffusion reflects promotes the chemical reaction of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) conversion at the interface of the medium [185,186]. About three-quarters of the theoretical capacity is derived from the conversion of Li2S4/Li2Se4, indicating that Li2S/Li2Se nucleation plays a key role in promoting the reaction kinetics of lithium batteries and improving electrochemical performance [187]. However, the diffusion of Li2S4/Li2Se4 on the medium largely depends on the conductivity of the medium. Because for conductive media, Li2S/Li2Se can directly nucleate on its surface. In addition, the appropriate and effective interaction of medium for lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) is effective to suppress their shuttle and accelerate the reaction kinetics [188,189]. Based on the above merits, the ECPs have excellent conductivity, which is beneficial to Li2S/Li2Se direct nucleation. Moreover, they also have excellent adsorbability, which creates efficient active sites for electrocatalytic conversion of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides). Hence, the ECPs can be as the mediators to accelerate the electrochemical reaction kinetics of Li-S/Se batteries. Furthermore, some ECPs also can be as the redox mediators to accelerate electrochemical reaction kinetics. For instance, when the nitrogens in PANI are introduced extrinsic Lewis acid/base pair (e.g. phytic acid [31]), their functional groups will experience a reversible transformation between deprotonated and protonated state to provide more nucleation sites for the Li2S precipitation. However, there are relatively few studies on adding dopants to this nitrogen functional group to improve the redox kinetics, which provides us with a broad research space in the future. Besides, we can also combine with other materials containing catalysis, e.g. metal oxides, sulfides, nitrides and phosphates through physical mixing or chemical doping to prepare functional materials with many functions such as conduction, adsorption and catalysis at the same time. 7 Conclusions and outlook The article reviews the application of common ECPs in Li-S/Se batteries, including PANI, PPy, PEDOT and PEDOT:PSS et al. In the past few decades, the applications of ECPs in Li-S/Se batteries have become an attractive area of research and aroused widespread interest. Although the excellent theoretical capacity and volumetric energy density make Li-S/Se batteries be regarded as promising energy storage batteries, their inherent shortcomings, such as low conductivity of S/Se, tremendous changes in volume during charge and discharge, and their notorious shuttle effect hinder their commercialization processes. Based on the above problems, various types of ECPs used in Li-S/Se batteries have emerged. Up to now, researchers have made unprecedented progress in the study of ECPs due to its excellent electrical conductivity and strong adsorption of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), which can significantly improve the performance of Li-S/Se batteries. Firstly, when ECPs are used as cathode materials for Li-S/Se batteries, they are used primarily as coating layer, S/Se host materials, sulfur copolymers, porous carbon precursor and a redox mediator. ECPs' excellent electrical conductivity and the ability to adsorb lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) enable them to be utilized reasonably when they are used alone or together with carbon materials and polar materials in the cathode. Secondly, when ECPs are used as modified separators/interlayers, their outstanding electrical conductivities and especially their ability to adsorb lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) determined that they could further accelerate electron transfer and intercept lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), which can improve the cycle stability of the battery. Finally, when ECPs are used as binders, they were directly used as binders, or physically mixed with other binders, introduced ions and doped sulfuric acid to improve adhesive performance. Compared with traditional binders, apart from the essential bonding ability, their conductivity and chemisorption render them can not only improve the conductivity of the electrode but also adsorb lithium polysulfides (polyselenides), as well as inhibit the volume expansion of the electrode. However, as shown in Table S1, various ECPs have different properties and applications in Li-S/Se batteries. Therefore, we should make full use of their advantages and improve their shortcomings to apply them to the appropriate parts of Li-S/Se batteries. In view of the above-mentioned encouraging results that have been discovered, great efforts are still needed to apply ECPs to the research direction of Li-S/Se batteries in the future. On the road of development, many challenges need to overcome. (1) Although ECPs are conductive, their conductivity is unsatisfied, which limits the development of ECPs alone as the conductive matrix of S/Se-based cathode materials. In response to the problem of conductivity, we may significantly improve their conductivities through doping techniques, such as chemical doping, electrochemical doping, acid-base doping and light excitation doping. In addition, other functional groups also can be introduced through physical mixings and chemical treatments (e.g covalent grafting, copolymerization and so on) to further improve their electrical conductivities and adsorbabilities of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) and electrolyte. In addition to modifying the original ECPs, we can also design different novel porous structures to encapsulate S/Se, restrain the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) and inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites, or develop novel types of multi-functional ECPs such as high conductivity, outstanding adsorption and strong catalysis. (2) The mechanism of ECPs about their adsorptivity and catalysis of the S/Se and lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) is not fully understood. Furthermore, the kinetics of Li-S/Se batteries with modified ECPs still need to be studied. Consequently, pioneered characterization techniques and theoretical calculations are vital for deeply understanding the underlying reaction processes and mechanisms in high-performance Li-S/Se cell. When compared with conventional ex-situ material test technologies, improved in situ and operando surface characterization methods such as operando IR, XPS, XAS and high magnification TEM tests that allow for promoting the ECPs evolution during the discharge–charge reaction will give us a profound understanding of the failure mechanism of high-performance Li-S/Se batteries. (3) Although in laboratory studies, some ECPs-based materials have shown excellent performance in Li-S/Se cells, and their practical feasibility remains to be further researched. In order to make ECP be widely used in practical applications in the future, we need to perfecttheir synthetic method and simplify their synthetic process, so that mass and efficient production with low cost can be achieved as soon as possible. In a word, the specific possible ways for the development of ECPs materials in high-performance Li-S/Se cells were presented in Fig. 18 . Although pure ECPs have some shortcomings, their excellent properties could be used in conjunction with carbon materials or polar materials to overcome their shortcomings. Of course, in future research, the physical and chemical properties of ECPs are still significant research areas for greatly enhancing the performances of the various parts of the Li-S/Se batteries. Simultaneously, as people pay more attention to this field, there will be fewer and fewer unsolved problems and more and more breakthroughs. Hence, the potential of ECPs and Li-S/Se batteries will be further expanded. We believe that through continuous improvements and researches on ECPs, the application of ECPs to Li-S/Se batteries makes it possible for them to have high sulfur utilization, high sulfur content, and low E/S ratio. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries and lithium-selenium (Li-Se) batteries, as environmental protection energy storage systems with outstanding theoretical specific capacities and high energy densities, have become the hotspots of current researches. Besides, elemental S (Se) raw materials are widely sourced and their production costs are both low, which make them considered one of the new generations of high energy density electrochemical energy storage systems with the most potential for development. However, poor conductivity of elemental S/Se and the notorious “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (polyselenides) severely hinder the commercialization of Li-S/Se batteries. Thanks to the excellent electrical conductivity and strong absorption of lithium polysulfide (polyselenide) about electronically conducting polymer, some of the above thorny problems have been effectively alleviated. The review presents the fundamental studies and current development trends of common electronically conducting polymers in various components of Li-S/Se batteries, which involves polyaniline (PANI) polypyrrole (PPy), and polythiophene (PTh) with its derivatives, e.g. polyethoxythiophene (PEDOT) and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS). Finally, the review not only summarizes the research directions and challenges facing the application of electronically conducting polymers, but also looks forward to the development prospects of them, which will provide a way for the practical use of electronically conducting polymers in Li-S/Se batteries with outstanding electrochemical properties in the short run.
